I acknowledge that, but trafficking is not, people-smuggling is not and immigration is not. Therefore the responsibility for those key aspects of this appalling scenario rests with the government and, most particularly, with the minister. Senator Ellison repeated today that existing Australian law was aimed at dealing with this issue, and he talked in particular about the introduction of the Commonwealth's Criminal Code Amendment (Slavery and Sexual Servitude) Act 2000. While I acknowledge that the legislation has merit, the fact is that it has been unsuccessful in prosecuting a single person—not one trafficker. While Minister Ellison made a point of saying there were some 19 investigations under way, nine of which are ongoing, we still have not had one prosecution.

I argue that the legislation is inadequate. I argue that we need a review. I argue that we need some kind of inquiry or investigation, whether that be through the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation or References Committee or perhaps even through the new Joint Statutory Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, which has evolved out of the old National Crime Authority committee. Australian law-makers have gone some way towards addressing the problem, yet we know that the legislation does not fully reflect new international agreements and standards set out by agreed-to trafficking protocols. The very starting point for us is to stop treating these women as criminals and rather as victims. We need to make sure that we can keep them in Australia, look after their welfare first and foremost, provide them with the opportunity to give evidence against their traffickers and then go after the traffickers. We need better procedures, better processes and better legislation, not more wilful blindness or abdication of duty.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Whereas the 1998 Synod of the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne carried without dissent the following Motion:

That this Synod regrets the Government's adoption of procedures for certain people seeking political asylum in Australia which exclude them from all public income support while withholding permission to work, thereby creating a group of beggars dependent on the Churches and charities for food and the necessities of life;

and calls upon the Federal government to review such procedures immediately and remove all practices which are manifestly inhumane and in some cases in contravention of our national obligations as a signatory of the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
We, therefore, the individual, undersigned Attendees at:
The Baptist Church, Armadale, Victoria 3143;
Kingsley College, a Wesleyan Methodist Bible College, Glenroy; and
Evening Mother's Union, St Paul's Anglican Church, Ringwood
petition the Senate in support of the abovementioned Motion.
And we, as in duty bound will every pray.

talk.start.para: Senator Allison (from 41 citizens).

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate
The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate:

That on Friday 19 October 2001, a grossly overcrowded boat, known as SIEV-X, carrying approximately 397 asylum seekers sank in international waters between fifty and sixty-five nautical miles south of Java, in an area that was at the time under intense surveillance by the Australian Defence Forces as part of Operation Relex; with the loss of approximately 353 lives; and that Australian authorities were aware of the departure of SIEV-X from Sumatra on 18 October, and yet there was no attempt by the Australian Defence Forces or Coastwatch to locate or intercept this boat, with a view to ensuring the safety of the people on board;

That during 2001, the Australian Federal Police conducted a secret People Smuggling Disruption Program in Indonesia, in cooperation with selected elements of the Indonesian Police Force and various other individuals; and that an Indonesian-based informant of the Australian Federal Police, Kevin John Enniss, has claimed to have sabotaged and sunk boats carrying asylum-seekers;

That there is a growing belief in the community that the Australian government and/or its agents deliberately neglected to ensure the safety of the lives of the asylum-seekers on board SIEV-X, and may even have been in some way responsible for the sinking of the boat as a deterrent against unauthorised asylum-seekers attempting to come to Australia by boat from Indonesia

Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to urgently pass a motion calling on the Prime Minister to establish an independent judicial inquiry with full powers to subpoena witnesses to investigate all the circumstances surrounding the disruption, departure and sinking of the asylum seeker boat known as SIEV-X, and all activities of the Australian Government, its servants, agents and collaborators in regard to SIEV-X, including:

1. All surveillance activities conducted by Coastwatch and the Australian Defence Forces in the area between Christmas Island and Indonesia; and all decisions regarding interception or non-interception of asylum-seeker boats and rescue or non-rescue of asylum seekers during the period of Operation Relex;
2. All activities by the Australian Federal Police and its partners, agents and informants to disrupt people smuggling in and from Indonesia;

3. All information reaching the People Smuggling Taskforce in the Prime Minister's Department and the DIMIA/AFP People Smuggling Strike Team, and all decisions made and actions taken by the members of those bodies.
4. All information reaching Ministers and their advisers relating to the above, and all decisions made and actions taken or authorised by Ministers and their advisers.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett (from 14 citizens).

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned calls on the members of the Senate to support the Australian Democrats' motion opposing Australia's involvement in pre-emptive military action or a first strike, against Iraq.
We believe a first strike would undermine international law and create further regional and global insecurity.
We also call on the Government to pursue diplomatic initiatives towards disarmament in Iraq and worldwide.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett (from 835 citizens).

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian national flag.
2. We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the nation's history.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

talk.start.para: Senator Kemp (from seven citizens).

subdebate.1.para: Senator Cook to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate adopt the following recommendations of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee in its report on materiel acquisition and management in Defence:

(a) that the Senate request the Auditor-General to direct that the proposed 2003-04 audit of the Defence Materiel Organisation (DMO) by the Australian National Audit Office include a cultural audit that will assess:
(i) DMO's espoused corporate values and standards and staff compliance with these,
(ii) management and staff values, behaviours and competencies measured against the capability requirement,
(iii) employee attitudes, morale, beliefs, motivation,
(iv) employee understanding of, for example, the DMO's customers, industry partners, strategies, business plans, roles and contributions to the overall mission of Defence,
(v) communication processes,
(vi) the effectiveness of change management programs, employee commitment to them and the extent of the benefits materialising, and
(vii) compliance with health and safety regulations;
(b) that the Senate request the Auditor-General:
(i) to produce, on an annual basis, a report on progress in major defence projects, detailing cost, time and technical performance data for each project,
(ii) to model the report on that ordered by the British House of Commons and produced by the United Kingdom Comptroller and Auditor General, and
(iii) to include in the report such analysis of performance and emerging trends as will enable the Parliament to have high visibility of all current and pending major projects; and

(c) that the Senate under standing order 164, order the production, upon its completion, of the report by the Director of Trials of the Review of Test and Evaluation in Defence, and refer the document to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee for examination and report.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ridgeway to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes that 5 May 2003 was International Midwives Day;
(b) recognises the vital role that midwives play in the Australian health system attending approximately 250 000 births in Australia each year, or 98 per cent of births;

(c) also recognises that midwives are the most appropriate and cost effective type of health care provider to be assigned to the care of women in normal pregnancy and birth, including the risk assessment and the recognition of complications;
(d) notes the problems still facing independent midwives and midwifery students in securing policies providing professional indemnity insurance;

(e) notes that the Australian College of Midwifery approached the Government for financial assistance on this matter and that its request for around one million dollars has so far been ignored, in contrast with the medical profession, whose professional indemnity interests have been advanced by the Australian Medical Association and the Government; and
(f) calls on the Government to meet with representatives of the midwifery profession in order to assist midwives in their inability to obtain adequate insurance cover.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ridgeway to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes with sadness the passing of former African National Congress (ANC) Deputy President, Mr Walter Max Ulyate Sisulu;
(b) remembers Mr Sisulu as a freedom fighter who dedicated his life to the struggle against apartheid and the oppressive former South African regime;
(c) recognises that Mr Sisulu co-founded the Youth League of the ANC and played a major role in the anti-apartheid campaign, a role which resulted in his imprisonment from 1964 till 1989; and
(d) pays tribute to Mr Sisulu's contribution to the freedom of black South Africans as well as being an inspiration for oppressed peoples all around the world.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

quote.para: (1) That a Select Committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Medicare, be appointed to inquire into and report by 26 June 2003 on the following matters:
The access to and affordability of general practice under Medicare, with particular regard to:
(a) the social and economic reasons for the establishment of Medicare in 1984;
(b) more recent developments in Medicare, with regard to:
(i) the impact of the current rate of the Medicare Benefits Schedule on practitioner incomes and the viability of bulk-billing practices, and
(ii) the impact of general practice and specialist shortages nationally and regionally in terms of patients' ability to access appropriate care in an appropriate time,
(c) the likely impact on access, affordability and quality services for individuals, in the short- and longer-term, of the following Government-announced proposals:
(i) incentives for free care from general practitioners limited to health care card holders or those beneath an income threshold,
(ii) a change to bulk-billing arrangements to allow patient co-payment at point of services co-incidental with bulk-billing reimbursement, and
(iii) the introduction of new safety nets with upfront `excesses', and
(d) alternatives in the Australian context that could improve the Medicare principles of access and affordability, within an economically sustainable system of primary care, in particular:
(i) whether the extension of federal funding to allied and dental health services could provide a more cost-effective health care system,
(ii) the implications of reallocating expenditure from the abolition or means-testing of the private health insurance rebate in terms of these alternatives, and
(iii) alternative remuneration models that would satisfy medical practitioners but would not compromise Medicare principles.

(2) That the committee consist of 7 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and 1 nominated by minority groups and independent senators.
(3) That the chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.
(4) In the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate.
(5) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(6) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(7) That the quorum of the committee be 3 members.

(8) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider.
(10) That the quorum of a subcommittee be 2 members.

(11) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(12) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

3. Report no. 38 of 2002-2003—Performance Audit—Referrals, Assessments and Approvals under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (presented to temporary chair of committees, Senator Knowles, on 10 April 2003).

5. Report no. 40 of 2002-2003—Performance Audit—R&D Tax Concession: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, the Industry Research and Development Board and the Australian Taxation Office (presented to the Deputy President on 22 April 2003).
6. Report no. 41 of 2002-2003—Performance Audit—Annual Reporting on Ecologically Sustainable Development (presented to the Deputy President on 7 May 2003).
7. Report no. 42 of 2002-2003—Performance Audit—Managing Residential Aged Care Accreditation: The Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency Ltd (presented to the Deputy President on 7 May 2003).
8. Report no. 43 of 2002-2003—Performance Audit—The Sale of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (presented to temporary chair of committees, Senator Brandis, on 8 May 2003).

para.inline: RETURNS TO ORDER PRESENTED TO THE PRESIDENT
SINCE THE LAST SITTING OF THE SENATE

subdebate.1.para: 1. Statements of compliance with the continuing order of the Senate of 20 June 2001, as amended on 27 September 2001, relating to lists of contracts are tabled by:
· agencies within the Employment and Workplace Relations portfolio (presented to the Deputy President on 1 April 2003).
· agencies within the Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs portfolio (presented to temporary chair of committees, Senator Brandis, on 4 April 2003).
· agencies within the Department of Transport and Regional Services and the National Capital Authority (presented to temporary chair of committees, Senator Knowles, on 10 April 2003).
· Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) (presented to the Deputy President on 23 April 2003).

· agencies within the Environment and Heritage portfolio (Environment Australia, Bureau of Meteorology, Australian Antarctic Division, Australian Greenhouse Office, National Oceans Office) (presented to the Deputy President on 28 April 2003).
· erratum to letter tabled on 25 March 2003 relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, ACIAR, AusAID and the Australia Japan Foundation (presented to the President on 13 May 2003).
2. Statements of compliance with the continuing order of the Senate of 30 May 1996, as amended on 3 December 1998, relating to indexed lists of files are tabled by:
· Comcare (presented to temporary chair of committees, Senator Knowles, on 10 April 2003).
· Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General (presented to the Deputy President on 15 April 2003).
· Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) (presented to the Deputy President on 28 April 2003).

para.inline: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE SENATE FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REFERENCES COMMITTEE REPORT INTO RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION OF ADF PERSONNEL

subdebate.1.para: 1. The Committee's report contains 34 recommendations, most of which are supported either in whole or in part. Six recommendations (3, 10, 11, 24, 27 and 31) are agreed with qualification, two recommendations (17 and 20) are under consideration and one (30) is implemented in part. Three recommendations (14, 22 and 23) are not agreed with.
2. The Government Response deals specifically with each of the 34 recommendations contained in the Committee's report, as follows:

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review all uniformed personnel listings at training and base support locations to ensure that:

subdebate.1.para: · Positions are available for uniformed ADF personnel to undertake respite posting.
· Positions are available for uniformed ADF personnel to practise their trade skills.

Navy is providing additional shore postings at Fleet Base West to better match the number of personnel serving at sea. In addition, Navy has implemented a range of initiatives to make the employment of personnel ashore more meaningful and beneficial to the development of individuals' professional skills. It is not correct that technical sailors `are not allowed to do anything but the most menial of technical tasks ashore'.
Army is undertaking a rolling program of establishment reviews examining the manning levels and location of Army units.
Air Force is the least affected by these issues. Certain occupational groups, such as Airfield Engineers or Electricians, are limited to certain locations, which can be problematic.
Navy is trialing the placement of technicians in contractor's workplaces. If successful, this practice may be more widely implemented.

Army does not rely on positions in training and base support locations to provide opportunities to practise trade skills. While an individual's needs are considered, the trades and skills required are determined by Army's need to deliver combat capabilities. Trade positions within the combat force provide the opportunity to practise a wide range of trade skills from basic to advanced levels, except for some very technical levels that are rightly within the base support area. Most instructional positions require use of trade skills. Army has embedded some positions in the Non Army Groups to provide opportunities for trade mastery in trades such as; ammunition technician, parachute rigger, aviation maintenance, electronic warfare and firefighter.

Air Force acknowledges that outsourcing of deeper level technical functions may lead to problems, such as limitations upon skill development, if not managed carefully. Career management agencies monitor potentially adverse postings carefully in order to ensure technical skills are maintained and enhanced.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that, as contracts expire, the Department of Defence review all base support commercial contracts to ensure that an ADF
wide standard of base support is provided and that a range of services, such as those included below, be provided as appropriate to each location.

subdebate.1.para: · catering services that meet the diverse needs of ADF personnel;
· secure, safe and hygienic living accommodation;
· leisure facilities;
· financial services; and
· basic retail services.
The standardisation of requirements and performance levels achieved with commercial support contracts on bases is being pursued by CSIG as existing contracts are renewed.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that future Defence reform should not be undertaken without:

subdebate.1.para: · an ADF Personnel Environment Impact Study (PEIS); and
· an accepted Implementation Plan which incorporates the establishment of an Implementation Team.

The Government sees reform as a continuous process of improvement. Not all reform activities will be of the scale of the highly successful Defence Reform Program. Where appropriate implementation teams will be established. This is the approach being taken with recent reviews such as the recent External Review of ADF Remuneration. (Nunn Review)
The Committee recommends that Headquarters DFRO be moved to co-locate with Defence Personnel Executive and the Headquarters of the Department of Defence at the Russell Office complex.
The co-location of DFRO within Russell precinct is being pursued as part of a wider review of Defence office accommodation in the ACT.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence develop a long-term strategic ADF marketing and advertising plan that supports recruiting by:

subdebate.1.para: · appealing to the real reasons for enlistment;
· targeting general, critical trade and wider ethnic groups; and
· promoting ADF links with the community.

This recommendation accords with Government defence policy to develop a strategic approach to ADF recruitment communication. Defence conducts extensive research to identify the real motivations that cause Australians to enlist in the ADF. Marketing and advertising plans actively target general and critical trade groups. The current marketing and advertising plans are designed to appeal to the widest audience possible. Defence recognises that the ADF is not proportionally representative of the wider Australian community and is pursuing a strategy aimed at communicating with and attracting a more diverse representation of the Australian population.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence, as a matter of priority, support and implement changes to streamline the current recruiting process as proposed by HQ DRFO:

subdebate.1.para: · providing adequate manning for DFRO to plan and conduct recruiting,
· developing unambiguous policies on pre-enlistment requirements (particularly for age, education, citizenship, psychology, medical and character [drug usage/conviction history]), and
· developing clear policies and procedures for enlistment, re-enlistment, Service transfer and medical disability restrictions.

Defence is committed to improving the recruiting process. Staffing is under continuous review to ensure it is adequately resources with appropriately skilled personnel. The quality of staff posted to DFRO has also been strengthened. Defence is reviewing ADF and single Service recruitment policies, such as re-enlistment, Service transfer, and medical standards to ensure that they do not impose inappropriate constraints on recruiting.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence ensures that the training capacity of the three Services be bolstered to match the recruiting effort.

subdebate.1.para: It is acknowledged that training systems must complement the recruiting process in terms of capacity and timing.
Current Navy recruiting targets can be met within the training system. Recruiting targets are at high levels and the training system is working at near capacity levels.
Similarly, the Army training system remains under some stress due to successful recruiting achievement. Training staff have been bolstered where necessary.
Air Force has strengthened ties between personnel planning, recruitment and training to ensure that `ab initio' training matches the recruiting effort.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Head of Defence Personnel Executive be made a member of the Defence Committee.

subdebate.1.para: An outcome of the Defence People Committee meeting held on 3 Jul 02 was the recommendation that HDPE be appointed a full member of the Defence Committee. Agreement out of session was sought from Defence Committee members. HDPE attended the Defence Committee meeting held 18-19 Jul 02 as a full member. Membership of the Defence People Committee and the Defence Capability and Investment Committee are now being reviewed

para.inline: The Committee recommends the Department of Defence review its strategic framework for personnel management to include:

subdebate.1.para: · a clear strategic communication plan to convey information on career management and personnel policy, and
· career streaming for ADF officers in HR management.

The Navy Personnel and Training Branch has a strategy to communicate information on relevant issues which is articulated, at the highest level in the Navy HR Management Plan. The strategy uses Navy News, Seatalk, general messages, websites and briefings to impart information related to personnel management.

Army is intent on improving communication on career management and personnel policy. Career interview tours of major Army locations is a continuing process. A `Stay Army' web page has been developed to provide options for reposting and trade transfer as alternatives to discharge. Army units have also been directed to appoint a Unit Retention Officer to act as a focal point within units for retention information and initiatives. Army has also developed a `Personnel Newsletter' similar to Navy's `Sea Talk' to provide regular updates on personnel matters.

Air Force has established a Communication Section within Air Force Headquarters to develop systems to enable better communication with members. The communication section comprises strategic communication, internal communication and reputation and brand management. An internal communication plan is being developed that will address the manner in which personnel management matters are communicated to the wider Air Force. The use of existing communication tools will be maximised, including the chain of command, Air Force News, e-mail networks, intranet and internet and base visits.
Defence accepts the need for a HR specialist stream in the ADF and is implementing this through the Services.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that aviation trades be structured to enable accreditation in the civil sector.

subdebate.1.para: Defence agrees that accreditation should be actively pursued whenever feasible.

The Riverina Institute of TAFE conducts all initial entry training for Aircraft Maintenance Engineers (AMEs) in the ADF. This training is conducted in accordance with the civilian requirements for qualifications in this trade at RAAF Base Forest Hill, and leads to qualifications from the nationally endorsed Aeroskills Training Package MEA97. These qualifications meet the aerospace industry's need for skilled and qualified people. In other aviation trades where national Training Package qualifications are not yet available, each Service has sought and gained national accreditations within the NTF leading to the award of Nationally recognised qualifications for their programs of VET and associated work experience. Defence is a member of the Industry Steering Group that is oversighting the national Training Package that will address these employments. The Training Package will address 13 areas of employment, including flight crew, air traffic controllers, ground handling staff, and aircraft refuellers.

It should be noted that there is a requirement for AME to be registered to maintain specific aircraft types. In general, aircraft in use in the ADF are not on the civil register. Personnel wishing to be employed in the civil aviation industry must have appropriate type endorsement and may need, therefore, to achieve some additional civil aviation authority requirements before they can gain civil employment.

It should also be noted that Navy and Army personnel are required to undertake specific aircraft technical and management training to perform tasks at different rank levels. For Army AME this involves, as Subject 4 for Sergeant training, undertaking approximately one year of the University of Southern Queensland's Bachelor of Technology. Navy requires its senior AME to have sufficient technical and management skill to undertake the duties of Flight Senior Maintenance Sailor. In RAAF there is no generic specialist AME training beyond LAC: promotion to Corporal is on time and performance.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that, where recruits are due to undertake trade courses which lack civil accreditation, they be advised of the fact before commencing those courses and given the opportunity to transfer to an alternative course.

subdebate.1.para: All applicants to the ADF are provided with both counselling and access to information that accurately reflects any civil accreditation for the avenue of entry to which they are applying. The ADF recruits to specialisation and musterings on the basis of capability requirements. It is not always feasible to allow recruits to arbitrarily transfer courses and therefore occupational group on the basis of an individual's desire to achieve civil accreditation for training provided.

Traditional trade training in the ADF is conducted in accordance with the requirements for the award of the appropriate nationally recognised qualification from the relevant national Training Package, where these are available. Each Training Command is a Registered Training Organisation (RTO) within the NTF(1). All three Service RTO have Quality Endorsed Training Organisation status.

In relation to specialist training, there are a number of ADF `trades', which have no direct civilian counterpart. For each of these trades the structured program of VET and associated work experience is mapped against related national Training Packages and, wherever appropriate, personnel receive Statements of Attainment against any unit(s) of competency satisfied. Each program is also taken through the national process of civil accreditation for the award of nationally recognised `enterprise' qualifications. Within the national VET system these programs are known as `accredited courses'. The extent of this activity across ADF can be gauged from Table One.
Table One: Nationally Recognised Qualifications Offered by the ADF Registered Training/Organisations Summary Detail—as at 24 April 2002(2)
(1) RAN No 0150 on the National Register, Australian Army No 0050 on the National Register, RAAF No 0546 on the National Register.

(2) The data provided was drawn directly from the National Training Information Service, a national database maintained by the Australian National Training Authority to record, inter alia, all nationally recognised VET awards and accreditations. This database may be ac cessed at www.ntis.gov.au

Defence has commenced a major project to develop the Defence Sector of the Public Safety Training Package. This project will identify and have nationally recognised units of competency and qualifications required by Defence, but not included in any other national Training Package.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review technical and non-technical trade training policies in the ADF to ensure that:

subdebate.1.para: · technical and non-technical personnel receive nationally recognised civilian accredited qualification,
· technical trade specialists are certified and licensed within the national training authority framework, and
· technical trade specialists receive continuation training and education.

As indicated in the response to Recommendation 11, ADF VET does receive civil recognition. This has been an ongoing activity since the mid 1990s, with all technical and non-technical categories/trades/musterings being reviewed regularly (in accord with the duration of their civil accreditations—three or five years) for the appropriateness and level of the civil qualification(s) awarded. As a consequence, all personnel within the ADF have the opportunity to receive nationally recognised qualifications for their category/trade/mustering training, and where conducted, promotion training.

Technical trade specialists receive continuation training and education. (See also the response to Recommendation 10). There is no common ADF approach to continuation training for each apparently similar specialisation. In the RAN and Army, technical trade specialists receive training at regular intervals to ensure their technical and managerial knowledge and skills develop.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review the manning of career management agencies to ensure a more equitable ratio of career managers to personnel and thereby improve career management procedures.

subdebate.1.para: The Services recognise the need to adequately staff career management agencies and will do so to the extent that appropriately qualified and skilled staff can be made available.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence develop an alternative career management policy for ADF personnel who are medically downgraded.

subdebate.1.para: Decisions on members' continuing employment following injury are based on capability requirements. Defence considers that individuals' needs and the requirement for a fit and healthy military workforce are adequately covered in the current provisions as follows:

Navy considers that the Medical Employment Category Review process detailed in DI(N) PERS 31-42 is a sound process which provides a reasonable organisational and individual balance. Medically downgraded members who remain in the Service cannot expect normal career progression as the Navy workforce system trains and promotes personnel to serve at sea at the next rank. Individuals unable to serve at sea will therefore not be competitive for such training and progression.

With a higher percentage of Army in the combat force and given the current high operational tempo, it is necessary for all members to meet minimum readiness requirements and be deployable. The current Medical Employment Category Review system provides some latitude to employ Medical Employment Classification Level 4 personnel who would normally be discharged. Army considers each case in a way that seeks to achieve an outcome that balances the individual's needs and the Army's duty of care. Individuals who are permanently non-deployable and who possess critical skills can be granted a Critical Skills Waiver for up to three years.

Air Force accepts that there may be some scope to review deployability requirements. For example, some occupational groups may only require a certain ratio of personnel to be fully deployable whereas others, by virtue of the nature of their work or the skill sets they possess, may not need to be deployable. Air Force is currently reviewing the need to apply the same level of fitness testing to all of its personnel all of the time.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review policies for the career management of specialist trades to enable:

subdebate.1.para: · the development of specialist career paths,
· continuation training to maintain equivalent civil qualifications eg medical clinical training, and
· a choice between specialist streaming and general streaming eg flying duties only/medical officer duties only without promotion.

Navy has implemented specialist career paths in certain areas. The Medical, Dental and Legal Officer streams all have specialist career progression and professional training systems in place. These streams include an element of continuation training to maintain civil qualifications.

Army is reviewing their requirements for specialists. Medical specialists and pilots are currently able to join for set periods and remain within these specialisations during that Limited Tenure Appointment.

Air Force recognises the need to tailor career management on the basis of occupational groups, and not simply for specialists. The Pilot and Engineer Sustainability Projects are good examples of such flexibility. Air Force agrees the need to provide personal and career development but primarily on the basis of organisational requirements rather than individual's aspirations.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence investigates and develops a new ADF personnel model with the following characteristics:

subdebate.1.para: · fixed terms of engagement;
· incremental retention incentives;
· incremental recognition of service; and
· a formal discharge package.

Defence is seeking to increase the flexibility of ADF engagement and conditions of service. A comprehensive Flexible Career Management System (FCMS) was examined and rejected in late 2001, largely because ADF members could not be convinced that it was not a mechanism for early termination of service—a clearly negative proposal for attraction and retention. Moreover, the resultant career management system would have been too inflexible to accommodate the constantly changing requirements of military capability, too expensive to administer and too staff intensive.

Nevertheless, the development of the proposal for a FCMS led to many flow-on initiatives that have been successfully introduced by the ADF and which have increased the ADF's capacity for flexibility in managing its people. The proposed fixed terms of engagement are being replaced by an initial period of service, which varies across the ADF and which is related to the cost of training and replacement. The universal incremental retention measures are being replaced by the application of retention / completion bonuses and retention allowances specifically targeted where they are needed and at the time that they are needed. These issues were also canvassed by the Nunn Review which remains subject to Government consideration. Methodologies have been developed to predict when these measures are most likely to be required.

Incremental recognition of service has always been a feature of ADF conditions of service. For example, superannuation entitlements increase significantly with years of service. Similarly, single accommodation entitlements were recently increased to provide a better lifestyle to those with more than five years of service.
In response to the suggestion for a `discharge package' a new Career Transition package has recently been introduced to provide better management of discharging members.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Government instigate a salary system for uniformed personnel that recognises their appointed responsibility in addition to rank, competency and experience.

subdebate.1.para: The Nunn Review of ADF remuneration arrangements has addressed this issue in detail. The recommendations are currently being assessed by Government.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Government review ADF benefits currently reported as fringe benefits on members' payment certificates where those fringe benefits have an unintended and unfair effect on family-related benefits and payments.

subdebate.1.para: This matter continues to be considered by the Government, and several FBT reporting exemptions have already been granted where unintended and unfair impacts have been felt by ADF members.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence investigates and reviews its classification of remote locality postings in order to ensure a more equitable distribution of benefits.

subdebate.1.para: This investigation continues with other Government departments.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence align the RLLT entitlement to match other government employee entitlements.

subdebate.1.para: The Government appointed External Review of ADF Remuneration Arrangements has made recommendations in relation to this issue which are currently under consideration by Government.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence investigate its spouse recognition policies to ensure they are equitable and aligned with other Government departments.

subdebate.1.para: The ADF's policy on recognition of spouses will be aligned, wherever possible, with other Government departments.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review HPAS to ensure it provides equitable housing assistance to ADF members in all real estate regions of Australia.

subdebate.1.para: Defence has recently reviewed the operation of the Home Purchase Assistance Scheme (HPAS) and is satisfied that the scheme provides equitable home purchase assistance to ADF members in all real estate regions in Australia.

HPAS was introduced on 1 July 2000 to provide a more equitable distribution of the financial assistance available to ADF members towards home purchase than was previously available under the initial purchase element of Home Purchase or Sale Expenses Allowance (HPSEA).

While HPAS provides a greater benefit to some members and less for others, in comparison with the previous arrangement the change has resulted in a far more equitable application of an existing benefit. In addition, the removal of the four-year time limit on initial home purchases has made HPAS available to a large number of members who were previously ineligible for assistance under HPSEA. As HPAS can be paid on the signing of a home purchase contract, the financial assistance is available at the time the member is incurring expenditure (final settlement).
2,647 members received a HPAS payment during the first year of its operation (the 2000/2001 financial year). This take up rate represents a 60% increase over the previous arrangement.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review the policy regarding own-home lease arrangements for ADF personnel to ensure they are not disadvantaged.

subdebate.1.para: Defence has recently reviewed the policy regarding own home lease arrangements for ADF personnel and is satisfied that personnel are not disadvantaged by the extant policy.

The long-standing and re-affirmed policy is that members are not eligible for housing assistance in their locality of posting if they have a suitable own home in that locality. If members are unable to occupy their home for reasons genuinely beyond their control, sufficient flexibility exists to cover such circumstances.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that Defence Housing Authority review its policy of selling old housing stock in established communities near bases and forcing Defence personnel to occupy housing considerable distance from their base.

subdebate.1.para: DHA does not have a policy of selling well-located housing stock. Old stock near bases has been traded in where it makes economic and customer sense. For example, at Amberley, old stock that was in the noise footprint has been sold and new houses have been acquired in Ipswich. In the annual DHA tenant survey for 2001, the customer satisfaction index for house location was 76.2%, representing an average satisfaction of 5.33 on the seven point rating scale used in the survey. In all areas, DHA seeks to improve this figure by disposing of stock that is not popular with members.

With respect to the Sydney example quoted at paragraph 5.21 in the report, very little inner Sydney stock has been sold. In the past five years, DHA has disposed of only four houses in Inner Sydney. On the other side of the ledger, 76 apartments have been added to the stock under the Inner City Apartment program, which seeks to trade off amenity for location. This trial program has now been extended to other capital cities, in recognition that lifestyles of the Australian community are changing and that many Defence members desire to live close to cities.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Government conduct an independent survey to assess the level of customer satisfaction with the accommodation assistance provided by DHA and recommend improvements.

subdebate.1.para: Defence has contracted a company to carry out a survey of personnel for their satisfaction of the full range of support services provided to ADF personnel by DHA. Additionally, Attitude Surveys and more regular topical issues surveys are now specifically addressing these matters.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence review its strategic communication plan for conveying family support information to Defence families to ensure a consistent message and availability of information.
Defence will continue to improve its strategic communication to ensure the consistency and availability of information to Defence families. Examples of recent improvements include:
The establishment of the DCO website with its local community information focus within a national framework;
The establishment of the Defence Family Matters newsletter with its focus on national family issues;
The provision of new locality information to posting families prior to relocation via a partnership between DCO and DHA;
The provision of information to deployed members and families through specialised mailouts from the National Welfare Coordination Centre and DCO.

These initiatives have built upon the long established information media of family newsletters that focus on local events and issues, the one-to-one information provided by Family Information Network for Defence and regular articles in the Service newspapers such as Seatalk.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence adopt a mandatory pre-enlistment spouse induction program as part of the ADF recruiting process.

subdebate.1.para: Defence has developed a Welcome to the ADF Family program, planned for introduction nationwide in October 2002, following a successful pilot which was conducted in February 2002 in Brisbane. Participation in this program is aimed at improving the communication between Defence and the family, and at assisting new recruits and families to negotiate successfully the early challenges associated with the military lifestyle. The program will be delivered post-enlistment, either while the new recruit is on recruit training or when he/she and family arrive at the first posting location. The curriculum will cover the information that a family that has already made the commitment to employment in the ADF needs to know, rather than pre-enlistment.

It should be noted that the Defence Community Organisation conducts Married Enlistee Interviews (MEI) for families referred by Recruiting Officers. Recruiting Officers use their discretion and refer where they have some concerns about the family's ability to adapt to the military lifestyle. The DCO interview may lead to a report that recommends against recruitment but the main purpose of the interview is to provide a brief to the family about the military lifestyle and an opportunity to reconsider the enlistment decision where family difficulties may ensue.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence ensure that all current and available resources are being used in the matter of spouse employment assistance and, as a matter of priority, investigate and implement additional lateral measures to provide spouse employment assistance.

subdebate.1.para: The Defence Community Organisation initiated a review and needs analysis of the existing spouse employment assistance programs in February 2002. The review will also suggest ways of improving the assistance currently offered. An independent consultant has been contracted to carry out the analysis.

para.inline: The Committee urges Commonwealth, State and Territory Education Ministers to reach consensus on the introduction of national standard school starting ages, standard grades and standard handwriting requirements.

subdebate.1.para: The Department of Defence and the Department of Education Science and Training (DEST) have jointly funded a study `Effects of Student Mobility on Learning Outcomes'. The report was delivered in August 2002. One of the recommendations of the study is for greater structural alignment of State and Territory education systems. Defence will work with DEST in engaging State and Territory Governments and Education authorities to progress these structural changes. In the interim a number of initiatives have also been recommended as part of the study to alleviate the difficulties associated with moving from school to school. These projects include developing an effective system for the transfer of student information from one school to another as well as promoting a best practice approach to responding to the needs of mobile students.

The issue of acceptance of handwriting across States and Territories was investigated as part of the mobility study. It is anticipated that this issue will be addressed by DEST in re-affirming the previous State and Territory agreement to accept different handwriting and promotion of this acceptance through ongoing professional development of teachers.

In May 2002 the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence launched the Defence School Transition Aide program which will see the employment of 68 part time aides within schools across Australia that have a significant number of ADF children enrolled. The Defence School Transition Aides will assist ADF children and families to settle into their school community more quickly as well as effectively prepare for their next posting.

As part of its range of assistance to ADF members and their families on posting, Defence provides Regional Education Liaison Officers who provide advice assistance with education issues in regard to such areas as school entry, grading system and hand writing.

The Committee recommends that the Government apply a concession to the Superannuation rules of MSBS to allow ADF personnel to access member and employer benefits as either lump sums or indexed pensions at the mandatory retiring age.

The MSBS is a regulated superannuation scheme meaning that it must comply with the Superannuation industry (Supervision) legislation preservation rules. These rules require that a scheme member's entitlements must be preserved in a regulated superannuation scheme until the member reaches his or her preservation age and has left the workforce permanently.

A concession has been given to superannuation schemes such as the MSBS with compulsory retiring ages earlier than the SIS preservation age and this permits, subject to scheme rules, superannuation entitlements to be taken as non-commutable pensions. Thus the MSBS employer benefit can be taken as a pension at age 55, because the scheme rules permit the benefit to be taken as a pension.
Since the MSBS member benefit is only ever payable as a lump sum, that part accruing after 1 July 1999 must remain preserved in a regulated superannuation scheme.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence amend the rules governing continuous service and eligibility for the MSBS Retention Benefit in the case of Maternity Leave.

subdebate.1.para: The MSB Act 1991 permits a period of maternity leave to be included in continuous service for MSB Retention Benefit purposes. The eligibility criteria require that the member elect to pay MSBS member contributions prior to the period of maternity leave ending.

As a consequence, the period of maternity leave is made continuous with other military service for both superannuation and MSBS Retention Benefit purposes. There is no discrimination because the member, who is on maternity leave, is treated in exactly the same way as any other female or male MSBS member who has been required to have a period of continuous service in order to satisfy the MSBS Retention Benefit eligibility criteria.

The Report of the Review of ADF Remuneration, currently under consideration by Government, has recommended that the MSBS Retention Benefit be abolished. This recommendation remains under consideration by Government.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence retain and develop the capacity for `direct to unit' Army Reserve recruiting.

subdebate.1.para: Army recognises the benefits of direct to unit (DTU) recruiting and will retain and develop it. Establishment changes have embedded additional capacity at the formation level within the Combat Force to manage DTU recruiting.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence investigates and introduces an incentive program to encourage Reserve service following full-time service.

subdebate.1.para: In July 2001, CDF directed that Head Reserve Policy and Head Defence Personnel Executive, in conjunction with the Services, develop a proposal to achieve the transfer of greater numbers of Permanent personnel to Active Reserve service upon completion of their full-time service.
A detailed study was commissioned to develop appropriate initiatives to encourage an increase in the transfer rate. This study is still under consideration within Defence.

In addition to this study, Head Reserve Policy initiated the High Readiness Reserve Category Conditions of Service Study to investigate, explore and evaluate attitudes of Reservists to the High Readiness Reserves and determine what conditions of service options may assist the Services to attract and retain Reservists to the High Readiness Reserves. This study is expected to be completed in late 2002.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence restructures the manning, equipment and training of the Army Reserve to match the new roles and tasks outlined by Project Army 2003, taking into account the difficulties for recruitment and retention of CIT training.

Project Army 2003, in conjunction with the Reserve Roles and Tasks study, acknowledges the vital contribution the Reserves make to Army capability. The establishments of Reserve units within the Combat Force have been progressively reviewed during 2001 to match them with the tasks envisaged under Project Army 2003. Common Induction Training (CIT) will remain, but is now available in modules to provide Reservists with more flexibility. Collective training within the combat force is being enhanced with affiliations formed between Regular and Reserve formations and units, again focussed on meeting Project Army 2003 requirements.

para.inline: JCPAA Report 388: Review of the Accrual Budget Documentation
Government Response to recommendations of a policy nature
1. Agencies with a shared outcome should:

subdebate.1.para: · identify the shared outcome and the contribution of other agencies in achieving that outcome in their Portfolio Budget Statements (PBS) and annual report;
· determine a lead agency with prime responsibility for that outcome; and
· consider entering into memoranda of understanding with the other agencies to clarify the responsibilities of each agency in achieving the shared outcome.

The Government notes the Committee's perception that “some agency outcomes statements are so broad and far reaching that as to be in effect outcomes shared with other agencies”. The intention has been that outcomes statements be agency-specific to allow an assessment of that agency's contribution to an outcome.

The Government agrees that there is benefit in clarifying outcomes requirements given the experience gained since outcomes statements were introduced in 1999-2000. The Department of Finance and Administration (Finance) is developing Outcomes Principles that will require the development of more specific, less aspirational outcomes statements where appropriate. This will reduce the overlap in most instances, but there will be situations where the concept of cross-portfolio outcomes may have application.
There are options under examination to address such situations. The identification of a lead agency and the development of Memoranda of Understanding are avenues receiving consideration.
2. The annual reporting requirements should be amended to require agency annual reports to be tabled by 30 September.

The ability of agencies and the Australian National Audit Office to finalise and audit financial statements earlier than they have done in the past is a key issue. Following the recent Budget Estimates and Framework Review, the Government agreed to earlier targets for the provision of financial information by agencies. Implementation of the targets will occur progressively over the next three years and the Government may then be in a position to reconsider the issue of deadlines for tabling of annual reports.
4. Agency outcome statements should:
· completely and clearly define their key objectives to reflect the impacts Government expects from their work;
· completely and clearly define the impacts Government expects from agency administered items; and
· accurately articulate the purpose of the relevant appropriations under the Appropriation Acts of the Commonwealth Budget.
Finance's website advice on specifying outcomes is explicit about the need to address the matters identified in this recommendation and reinforces this guidance through the provision of examples.

In practice, closer linkages are desirable between outcomes and the supporting outputs and administered items. In some cases, subject to the requirements of relevant Ministers, a disaggregation of existing outcomes resulting from the expected application of the Outcomes Principles mentioned above will address this need.

5. Agencies with a single broad ranging outcome, or with a small number of highly aggregated outcomes, should identify intermediate outcomes to indicate the shorter-term objectives on the path to achieving their higher-level outcomes.

It is expected that the improved specification and, where necessary, disaggregation of outcomes discussed above, will be the primary avenues to address this recommendation. However, it is also agreed that where necessary, outcome statements can usefully be supplemented by the identification of intermediate outcomes covering desired shorter-term impacts. Existing guidance on the Finance website notes the latter option.

6. Agency performance measures identified in the PBS must always be accompanied by a comparative standard. Agencies should report their performance against this comparative standard in their annual reports, with a discussion if actual performance significantly varies from that expected.

The Performance Management Principles, promulgated in 2001 by the previous Minister for Finance and Administration, note that performance information is more effective where performance can be compared against specific benchmarks, targets or activity levels.

The guidelines for Portfolio Budget Statements (PBS) will be amended to require such information be specified for performance measures identified in the PBS. However, the guidelines will also indicate that in exceptional cases where it is not possible or desirable to identify a quantitative comparator, a qualitative measure should be applied. The guidelines will note that in all situations, further qualitative or non-targeted performance information can be identified where this adds perspective.

The annual report requirements promulgated by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet already adequately indicate the nature of the linkage between the two documents in respect of reporting against performance targets.
11. The Final Budget Outcome (FBO) should be audited by the Australian National Audit Office.

The Government notes that the Final Budget Outcome must be published by 30 September, in accordance with the Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998. Under present arrangements this deadline is met with little time to spare. Therefore, the introduction of a complete audit process would compromise this legislative requirement. As the individual agency accounts that are consolidated into the FBO are audited, there is already an implicit audit process undertaken.

The Consolidated Financial Statements (CFS) for the Commonwealth are already audited by the Australian National Audit Office. Under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 the CFS must be tabled within five months of the end of the financial year. Given that audit of the CFS already provides assurance on aggregate financial statements, the Government does not consider it necessary to add another layer of checking for the FBO with associated consequences for what is already a tight FBO timetable.
