I am sure he is much more able to answer for himself, for starters, and to be in a position where he can have people defend him. Many people who have survived or endured child sexual assault have had nobody to defend them or stand up for them and it is well and truly beyond time that we now start to do so. Again, the other part of the motion that I believe is most important and significant is the call on the Prime Minister to establish a royal commission into child sexual abuse.

I have made my view clear—as have the Democrats, as have many other people around the country—that the Governor-General should resign. Other people have a different view. In my view, if the Governor-General stays in the office, the office will continue to be severely compromised and the Prime Minister will be seen to be continuing to not address the issue. If the Governor-General stays in the office, I believe it will continue to send a signal that the Prime Minister and the Governor-General do not believe child sexual assault is a serious enough issue and that it can just be dismissed as not that big a deal.

That is a terrible message to the Australian people. I think it will send a particularly painful message to people who have been touched by child sexual assault, whether they are survivors or the families of survivors. But that is even less important than the need to address this issue on a comprehensive basis. If the Governor-General stays in office, it is unfortunate; it is not the end of the world. But it is quite literally the end of the world for many people if they cannot get their voices heard about this issue.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, mentioned that the Governor-General came from a social services background, rather than some of the other traditional backgrounds for governors-general. I think that is probably a good thing. As people may know, my background is in social work and community work. I do not profess to be a complete expert on the issue, but I have had contact and done work with individuals who have had their lives absolutely destroyed by sexual assault and sexual abuse. That basic fact should not be forgotten. This destroys lives, and that is why it is literally for some people the end of the world, the end of their world, if they are not able to get justice.

Another reason why the Democrats believe a royal commission is so important is for the children of today and the future. In some ways, it is too late—far too late—for many people, but we must do what we can to ensure that everything is done to prevent this occurring. We all live in an imperfect world. I am not being utopian. There will always be these sorts of acts committed. But we can do an enormous amount better. It is true, as Senator Hill said, that the majority of sexual assaults and sexual abuses occur within families or extended families, amongst people known to the victim. There are issues there as well.

But we also need to look at our institutions, both those institutions that care for children and those various departments that work with families. We see repeated inquiries, repeated acknowledgements by governments, by people in the field that the resources and the processes of those departments are not adequate. To say that is just a state issue is simply a cop-out. This federal government provides enormous amounts of funding. Some may argue about whether it is enough in specific areas, but we provide an enormous amounts of funding at the Commonwealth level to states to undertake certain activities.

What this federal government should be doing—something a royal commission can quite comprehensively do—is putting in place a set of standards, of benchmarks that must be met, whether it is by state departments, whether it is by churches, whether it is by sporting groups, whether it is by schools; you do not get money, you do not function, you do not have the right to oversee the care of children unless you have your act together.

Some organisations have got better in recent years—we have started to move towards screening of people who have contact with children, with criminal checks, character checks, mandatory reporting, putting in place procedures for dealing with complaints—but I do not think anybody could suggest that we do not still have a long way to go. I would suggest that it is not only clearly in the interests of survivors and institutions but in the interests of the government to have a proper, decent, comprehensive inquiry that can look into this fully, because there are plenty of other instances out there. Anybody in this place who has raised these issues—and I am sure Senator Murray would affirm this—knows that all you have to do is show an interest in trying to raise these issues and promote these issues and you will have people coming to you who are desperate to get their situation addressed, to be acknowledged.

There are plenty of other cases, other situations, other dioceses, other churches where cases will come to light in the future. If the government wants to have them dribble out, case by case, instance by instance, month after month, year after year, repeatedly being shown that they could have acted and have not, I would suggest that is not in their political interests. Of course, I am not particularly interested in the political interests of the government, or the rest of us, when we are talking about this issue; I am interested in getting action to try to prevent this sort of issue from coming to the fore.

There have been over 100 clergy from the Catholic and Anglican churches alone who have been convicted of child sexual assault in the past five years with thousands of assaults on children, allegations that have been put forward by the Voices group in Australia's first sexual assault class action. The particular report and incident we are talking about relate to simply one diocese of one church in relation to a small number of cases in a specific period of time. There is an argument that has not been put forward today but has been put forward by some in the community that we should stop criticising the Governor-General because, sure, he made a mistake but it was a long time ago; standards were different back then. Firstly, I do not think 1993 was that long ago; nor was 1998 or 1999. The fact is that hundreds of thousands of Australians are still paying a terrible price for these so-called standards. I am not sure that they were ever official standards—in fact, they certainly were not; they were unspoken, institutionalised standards—but they deserve to be highlighted as completely inadequate and should be condemned. The only way of doing that is by sending a message that the government should take this seriously. The Senate certainly takes this seriously.

We can all say individually that this is a serious issue, but that does not cut it with people anymore. People want action; people want direct acknowledgment. We have to acknowledge that the actions of Dr Hollingworth in his previous role were not that long ago, were grossly inadequate, put children at risk and put the interests of the institution and the perpetrator—someone who was later convicted—ahead of the interests of the victims. We as a house of parliament or as people who are in leadership roles in the community cannot simply wave that away as a simple error of judgment. That is why I believe we as a Senate need to send a strong message, and that is why I believe the Governor-General and the Prime Minister should send a strong message. It is not pleasant; no-one is suggesting it is. I am not saying the Governor-General should be tarred and feathered for the rest of his life. All I am saying is that he is no longer adequate to perform in the position that he is in. It would send a very strong positive message about child sexual assault if he were to recognise that and stand down.

In any case the Democrats—and I urge others in this chamber to do the same—continue to push for action on the issue of a royal commission because it is what we believe is necessary. We believe that it is the best way forward on this issue. It should continue in many ways beyond the debate about the Governor-General—that simply serves to draw attention to the importance of the issue. We need to get action for people. The Prime Minister said today in question time, `Some people say you're better off spending $60 million on services than on a royal commission.' If that means the government is going to announce an extra $60 million in spending, that is great, but let us have a royal commission as well. (Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not think anyone in this chamber would quarrel with the proposition that child sexual abuse is one of the most repulsive crimes that one can imagine. We now know from recent painful episodes and a lot of heart-rending stories that it can often have devastating and lifelong consequences. I do not think we should proceed on the basis that it is necessary to have a royal commission when in recent years there has been almost an avalanche of evidence to indicate the nature and extent of the problem. One can always say that there may be more to be uncovered, but the real issue is how you tackle that. Difficult though it may be, the problem is multifaceted and in many respects originates from family problems. That being the case, there is a very good argument that more attention should be given to devising solutions that are likely to deal with the problem.

speech.para: I remember the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which I think cost the Commonwealth some $60 million. It came up with a whole series of recommendations which did not shed any serious light on what most people in the community already appreciated. It did not do anything to alleviate the problems, although it certainly made a lot of lawyers a bit wealthier. But, at the end of the day, I do not think anyone would seriously argue that it was a major step forward in trying to address a very serious social problem.

Firstly, we are being asked to establish a royal commission and, secondly, the Governor-General is being called on to resign immediately. This has to be seen in the context of recent events. Certainly, there is no doubt that in recent days events have moved very quickly. Regarding the decision by Dr Hollingworth to stand aside, particularly to give himself more time to defend himself against the allegations that have been made in respect of events occurring some 40 years ago, and which may well result in serious litigation in Victorian courts, and also for him to ultimately consider his overall position with regard to the importance of the role that he occupies, I would have thought that was a fair and just approach to a very difficult problem.

When we look at some of those who have expressed a view in recent days, we find the former Governor of Victoria, Dick McGarvie. He has been described as a constitutional expert, but I think it is also fair to say in this context that Dick McGarvie is one of those people who can claim very serious credit for having turned the Labor Party around in the sixties. He was one of those instrumental in reforming the stranglehold that the Left had on the Labor Party. Having worked with him in the courts and having known him for very many years, I can say that he has been a voice of moderation and someone who has always had the national interest at heart. In his view, Australia would face its worst constitutional crisis if Dr Hollingworth was forced to resign. He says it is entirely appropriate that he stepped aside. He says:
A forced resignation would do untold damage to the office of the Governor-General and deliver inappropriate power to the media and opposition.

I say in passing that it is very easy to make sweeping statements that one of the highest positions in the land can be devastated unless someone immediately takes some action that happens to suit their political purposes. It is very easy to have rhetoric on either side of the argument, but I do not think that Dick McGarvie is someone who is given to grandstanding rhetoric at all. He is simply expressing a very considered and thoughtful view.

Sydney University Associate Law Professor Don Rothwell described yesterday's decision as a wise circuit-breaker, and the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney said the right decision had been made. Of course, we have had people like Terry O'Gorman, with whom I would not always agree, characterising what is going on now as little more than a witch-hunt. It is very important that Dr Hollingworth not be hounded from office, that we look at how we are in this current position. One of the things that I think really ought to exercise the minds of the Labor Party is the role played by Lindsay Tanner, because this is a full-frontal attack on some of the most important institutions in our community. People have an entitlement to apply for suppression orders. They are entitled to argue their case. It is a matter for the judges to make a decision. You can appeal those decisions if necessary. But there is no right at all for a member of parliament to simply flout that power of the court and say, `I believe it is in the public interest.' Often when politicians use that term they are really saying, `It is to our political advantage.' But let me read from a letter which I thought was very instructive for Mr Tanner and those who might be inclined to support him, because this is clearly not from a coalition supporter:

Lindsay Tanner's cowardly move against the Governor-General again reveals federal Labor's front bench as a group of opportunistic head kickers, devoid of constructive policy initiatives. Fractured by internecine warfare and leadership squabbles, Labor is forced to resort to tearing down tall poppies et cetera.
He goes on to say:
Many people believe it's time for a change to a more progressive and caring government.

talk.start.para: (Senator Cook)—Minister, there was an unparliamentary description of Mr Tanner at the beginning of that letter. I think it should be withdrawn.
—I am simply reading—
—You should withdraw it.
—You have taken points of order on that.
—Are you saying that I cannot read from a letter?
—You cannot quote it.
—If you say that it is not appropriate, can I make the broader point—
—Do you withdraw it?

—I withdraw it. But I make the broader point, which I think I have already made, that here is someone who goes on to argue that he does not support the government of the day, that he believes there should be a more caring alternative—and presumably he regards the Labor Party as better qualified in principle—but he does take the strongest exception to the behaviour of Mr Tanner. Therefore I think it is instructive to look at what Mr Tanner has said. What he told Alan Jones the other day was that ultimately it is open for the courts, but of course he has done precisely the opposite. He was asked:

speech.para: But you know yourself that, once his name—
that is, Dr Hollingworth's—

gets into the public place in relation to such a serious and grievous charge as rape, you can talk until the end of your life and you'll never be able to expunge some references to that and its association with you.
Mr Tanner said:
Look, I think that is probably fair comment ...
Finally, he said:

If there are legal proceedings on foot then it is wrong for a party who is in one of the most senior positions in the land like the Governor-General to seek suppression orders with respect to those legal proceedings.

I do not know whether Mr Tanner is unaware of it, but the fact seems to be beyond doubt that Mrs Jarmyn was the one who sought the original suppression order. We know from some newspaper reports that she felt very passionately that it was in her interest not to have these matters in the public arena prematurely. That being the case, one would have thought that her wishes, and presumably the wishes of those who might inherit any legal rights in respect of the action, should be acknowledged and respected, but that is not what Mr Tanner has done at all.

Mr Tanner has effectively taken it upon himself to say that he does not give a damn about the rights of citizens or litigants; if there is a public figure involved then they ought to be outed. That of course is in the context where we are talking about an action being taken by a private citizen against a public figure, and it is very difficult—almost impossible, I would have thought—to say on the one hand that matter ought to be exposed but at the same time you can protect the rights of that individual, who in this instance clearly wanted the matter not to go public. What you are effectively doing is saying, `If I think there is a big fish there, I will put my interest in exposing that person ahead of the interests and concerns of the private citizen.' I do not think that is a very healthy sign of a democracy at all.

I leave it to the courts. If the parliament wants to say that it is not open to public figures to obtain to suppression orders, let it say that. If people want to argue against public figures being entitled to benefit from suppression orders, they have a right to do that. Of course, ultimately, judges are much better qualified than any of us to make those decisions. They can take account of the public interest, they can take account of the rights of the parties and, as I say, you can appeal those decisions in any event.

By placing questions on notice for purely political purposes, Mr Tanner clearly intended to render a legal suppression order ineffective. That is a matter of enormous concern. If we are talking about someone resigning, it should be Mr Tanner, because Mr Tanner is a serial offender. I am sure that members of the Senate will be aware that, on 19 March, he said in relation to Ron Walker:
Ron Walker has effectively used Grand Prix and taxpayers' money to buy his way onto the Fairfax board.

That is in the face of Fairfax absolutely disputing that, in any shape or form, Mr Walker had anything to do with the placing of the advertisements, Mr Walker himself saying that on the public record, Fairfax contacting the office of Mr Crean and advising him, and Mr Crean's office—I think Mr Crean personally—saying that he would not allow it to go further. Yet what has happened? Mr Tanner is able to say these things with impunity. When I first came into this place, every couple of weeks, so it seemed, Senator Ray was challenging people to go outside `cowards' castle' and make these sorts of allegations and have them properly tested.

talk.start.para: —You used to make allegations too.
—If it was a valid point then, it is a valid point now.
—And to you.

—Okay, and to me. I am not holding myself out to be holier than thou. I am simply saying that, when you are given every warning, when you are told that there is no substance to allegations, that is a very different situation to when you make an allegation that you have reason to believe is accurate but others vigorously dispute and you say, `Go outside and test it.' That is not what has happened here. This is Mr Tanner being told that there is absolutely no evidence to support his allegation and nonetheless saying it here, and being challenged subsequently. Of course he has not said `boo' since. I note that Paul Sheehan in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day said that he thought Mr Tanner's attack on Ron Brunton for his recent appointment to the board of the ABC was simple defamation, for saying he was effectively equivalent to Norm Gallagher, who—I do not think any of us need to be reminded—was not a very salubrious individual.
—Ron Walker used to do deals with him.

—There may have been executives of Hudson Conway who did, but I doubt very much that you could ever demonstrate that Mr Walker sat down and had a cup of tea with Norm Gallagher. I have never heard or read of anything to that effect, but, as you well know, Senator Ray, the building industry was a very unhealthy place to operate—on either side of the fence—and Norm Gallagher was probably one of the principal examples of why it was such a nasty place. If I could just say in passing, as a former member of the Builders Labourers Federation—because I was forced to join—I can remember—
—You wouldn't pay otherwise, being a parasite.
—I was prepared to do an honest day's work and get paid for it, but they told me, `No ticket, no start.'
—Now you get free TVs.

—Perhaps we had better not change the subject too much. Senator Ray is very good at trying to discover a new and different issue to take you away from the principal matter of concern. I am simply saying that, if we are seriously looking at who ought to resign and who ought to require resignation, it ought to be Mr Crean requiring Mr Tanner to stand aside, because it is quite clear that Mr Tanner is out of control.

—No-one suggests that I am out there flouting my leader on a daily basis, but it is quite clear what Mr Tanner does. Mr Crean went on radio the other day and when he was asked, `Are you comfortable with the way Lindsay Tanner flushed this out by putting these questions on notice?' he said, `Look, it's happened, Steve.' `Shouldn't he have talked to you about that?' `Yes, he should have. He didn't, but this has happened and we've got to move on.'

speech.para: This is someone who has no regard at all for the party structure or for anyone other than himself. If Labor thinks that that helps its cause, I do not and I do not think the public for a moment thinks it does. In fact, all that has happened in recent days is that there has been a monumental muddying of the waters because of an allegation that takes most people's breath away—one that is 40 years old and one that seems to have emerged only very recently in circumstances that probably deserve a lot more investigation. To effectively put that into the public arena against the wishes of the parties and the courts seems to me to be utterly indefensible. I am simply saying that I think the proper course of action is not to be calling for more blood at this point but to allow everyone to settle down and have some clean air, allow Dr Hollingworth to properly defend himself and consider his position and, for those who want to seriously address problems of child abuse, to really look seriously at some of the issues that governments have a role to play in solving.

talk.start.para: —From the outset, let me say that parliament has virtually no powers in relation to the Governor-General. The Senate has no role in the appointment of a Governor-General. We are not required to confirm executive appointments as the US Senate does. The dismissal of a Governor-General is clearly not a function of parliament. I have no regrets that this is in fact the case. It is, however, quite within the purview of the parliamentary process for it to express a view on the performance or otherwise of a Governor-General. The effective operation of the provisions of the Constitution is always relevant to the parliament. Furthermore, the Australian government often has to make representations on human rights issues. For instance, we are constantly making representations in Cambodia, on people-smuggling and on the eradication of Australian paedophiles operating in that particular area. What credibility do we have when our own head of state has question marks hanging over his head in relation to this?

speech.para: Governors-general are appointed by executive government. Indeed, it is really almost now evolved as an appointment and prerogative of a Prime Minister. Over many years prime ministers almost themselves have appointed governors-general. It is ratified by cabinet, but all the spadework is done by a prime minister. I, as deputy leader in the Senate, was certainly consulted on the matter of Bill Deane, as were the leader in the Senate and the Deputy Prime Minister. But it was then put to cabinet as an appointment without further consultation. On this occasion we have heard from the Prime Minister's own lips that Dr Hollingworth was appointed by him, and him alone. Not even Mrs Howard, rather strangely, had a say on this occasion.

It is also true to say that such appointments are formally approved by the Queen. But it is many years since a royal head has sought to interfere in the choice of Governor-General. When an Australian Prime Minister, James Scullin, decided to appoint Australia's first native born Governor-General he was met with virulent opposition from his then conservative opponents. That happened again when Bill McKell was appointed. The conservative antecedents of the Liberal Party opposed it. But, more interestingly, in the case of the Scullin appointment, George V and the palace also opposed it rigorously. It was only through the firm intervention and the firm arguing of James Scullin that Isaac Isaacs was appointed as Governor-General.

Dr Hollingworth's appointment attracted some criticism. Some people harped on the fact that church and state should be separate, without ever demonstrating that Dr Hollingworth's appointment in some ways abrogated that principle. To me it was an indication that this country was over sectarianism, that it is possible to have a senior religious leader of whatever persuasion as head of state. The Constitution, practice and commonsense all dictate that a Governor-General's tenure is a matter for executive government. In turn, executive government must take responsibility for their appointments, whether they are good, bad or indifferent. Governments must ensure the integrity of the office of Governor-General. Failure to remove a flawed Governor-General may leave the government open to the charge that such a Governor-General will be indebted to the government and not able to properly exercise those powers granted by the Constitution.

The Senate, of course, does have one area of scrutiny available to it with regard to the office of Governor-General, and that is the examination of its funding and the acquittal of its expenditure. It has never been properly established whether a Governor-General has the right to expend public funds to defend himself in what are essentially private matters. For instance, should the office have the right to hire without tender public relations gurus at several thousand dollars a day at taxpayers' expense? This is not to be critical of Mike Smith or Andy Reynolds—they were hired to do a job and they gave it their best shot—but their role was about spin. It was about protecting a position, not about revealing the truth or compensating victims.

Those coalition members who were critical of the funding of some aspects of Carmen Lawrence's legal costs are now notably silent about the expenditure on behalf of the Governor-General. Such expenditure might be justified if an individual were embroiled in a dispute because of the office that they held. It is a pity some Liberal Party members were not mature enough to understand this in the case of Ms Lawrence. It is becoming clear, however, that the Governor-General will meet his own legal expenses in the Melbourne court case. The opposition has not hesitated to scrutinise expenditure by the office of the Governor-General, and we have always received courteous cooperation. I might take the opportunity here to pay tribute to the outgoing Official Secretary to the Governor-General, Mr Martin Bonsey, the timing of whose departure has nothing to do with current events. He has been a model public servant who has faithfully and competently supported the last two governors-general.

The motion we are considering today was always going to be debated in this chamber, irrespective of the allegations relating to rape that emerged last week. It is essential to keep this issue separate from those matters pertaining to paedophilia and the Anglican Church. The Governor-General should have stood aside or resigned over those Queensland matters the moment the board of inquiry published its findings. The rape allegations will be settled through the judicial process. Dr Hollingworth must be given the presumption of innocence. If civil proceedings in Melbourne fail on a technicality, this will leave Dr Hollingworth in the intolerable position of the allegations having been made without the opportunity for him to disprove them in a court of law. There may be a myriad reasons why such allegations did not emerge at the time of the alleged event, but trying to assess evidence 38 years later, based on one photograph, makes justice difficult to contemplate.

I find it hard to understand why he has to stand aside now rather than when the court case was taken. Clearly, the Prime Minister's motive is to take political pressure off himself rather than to assist the Governor-General. The Prime Minister has totally failed to explain why he did not ask the Governor-General to stand aside either when the allegations were first made or when they were first taken to court. Nor is there any explanation as to why the Prime Minister did not inform the Leader of the Opposition of these allegations. Such low-rent behaviour from the Prime Minister surprises nobody on this side of the chamber. The real explanation for the Governor-General's standing aside lies not in the rape allegations but in the findings of the diocesan board of inquiry. It was not just dealing with the far distant past, as has been mentioned, I think, by Senator Bartlett; it was dealing with events that occurred within the last 10 years.

If Dr Hollingworth was not able to honour the position of public trust that was vested in him as Archbishop of Brisbane, then there is no certainty that he can do so as Governor-General. It was his decision to put the protection of the institution of the church ahead of protecting vulnerable minors that disqualifies him from public life. Allowing a priest to remain in the ministry in the knowledge that he had committed sexual abuse was a serious error of judgment or more. The board of inquiry found that this decision was untenable. Dr Hollingworth himself has admitted that he made a serious error in doing so. What we do not know, what is not clear and what we cannot establish is why Dr Hollingworth did not intervene. In the absence of a credible explanation, one can only assume that the good of the church was placed ahead of the good of certain individuals. The Governor-General was tardy in dealing with these paedophilia allegations; he was never tardy when it came to appointing a PR expert to defend himself. Using Australian Storyas his first line of defence was tactically inept. Either you have an open press conference or you speak to no-one at all. Setting up preconditions where you are protected from scrutiny but get your story over was bound to fail. Having to reshoot certain aspects of the Australian Story episode also greatly dented the Governor-General's credibility. Ascribing blame to a 14-year-old was inept indeed. This lack of sensitivity was further reflected in the now revealed correspondence with the victims' families. These families need more than just sympathy. They do not require revenge, but they do require understanding.

It has now been revealed that the Governor-General is unhappy with the board of inquiry. The claim is now made that natural justice has been denied to him. It is claimed that there was no opportunity for cross-examination. One wonders why these objections were not made when the inquiry was set up. There was every opportunity for Dr Hollingworth to give extensive evidence to this inquiry or fully participate in the inquiry, yet he chose not to do so. It is hard to blame the Anglican Church in Brisbane. They wanted an official inquiry into all of this, but the Howard government declined. Yesterday the Prime Minister virtually endorsed the Governor-General's legal critique of the board of inquiry, conveniently forgetting his own refusal to countenance a government endorsed inquiry. Indeed, yesterday he could have called for such an inquiry. Today he could set up such an inquiry, but he fears the results of such an inquiry.

Supporters of the Governor-General claim the whole issue is a witch-hunt. There is no doubt that the feeding frenzy in the media has been most unedifying and that Dr Hollingworth would be stunned by some of the vitriol directed towards him. His close family in particular have complained, and one has to acknowledge the pain that they have and are suffering through all of these events. That is the nature of Australian public life and that is the nature of the Australian media: to turn so viciously on anyone when the smell of blood is in the air. The way the media interfere in these particular matters is not a particular tribute to our way of life. Nevertheless, if you take a public job, you are open to public scrutiny, and you should know that before you sign up.

Dr Hollingworth's family are not the only family to have suffered. There are other families that have suffered. Children have suffered because society and the Anglican Church failed to protect them, and there has to be some accounting of this. It is not that the media has been totally one-sided. Most of the right-wing hack columnists have supported the Governor-General, not on the issues but out of tribal loyalty. One has only to look at the puerile conspiracy theories of Mr Piers Akerman to see that the debate has been debased. This has been matched by some of the republicans, who just want to belittle the office of Governor-General and, again, do not address the issues. In the end, only Dr Hollingworth can determine his future. If he wants to rely on the current Prime Minister, he has found a poor ally. Political expediency will be paramount when it comes to the prime ministerial advice on what the Governor-General should do.

I have no doubt that there have been worse governors-general than Dr Hollingworth. In the past, they were not subject to the brutal scrutiny that applies today. Weaknesses were overlooked or, indeed, covered up. We will not get much scrutiny from coalition members in this parliament on these issues. They have been directed by their chief whip not to comment publicly on this matter. So the party of individuality has become the party of conformity. We know that Dr Hollingworth is gone. How do we know it? The old defence team, Senator Hill and Senator Alston, has come down. The old Mal Colston defence team is here, with the same inept performance. I feel sorry for Dr Hollingworth that that is the best defence he will probably have. We will not, of course, see the Inspector Javert of paedophilia, Senator Heffernan, down here, because this is an appointment of the Prime Minister's. Those issues will not be exposed and pursued by him, because they are too close to home.

One issue that has arisen—and Senator Alston certainly commented on it—is: should parliamentary privilege be able to override a suppression order issued by a court? I have no doubt that parliament has that right. The question is: should it exercise it? Is there a distinction between criminal and civil cases? If it is not an abuse of privilege, is it a misuse of privilege? It may well be an issue that we should reflect on, not in these circumstances, but over a longer period of time. It may well be that either the House of Representatives or the Senate privileges committee should examine this. But, at the moment, there is no standing order that would prevent a senator or member from raising, under the cloak of privilege in the parliament, matters to do with a suppression order. Whether they should or should not do so we should look at in the long term.

This motion calls on the government to have a royal commission into child sexual abuse. It is probably the only way that one can properly deal with these issues. Royal commissions were not always witch-hunts. If you look at the record on them prior to the Second World War, they concentrated on solutions rather than on apportioning blame. It was from the time of the Petrov royal commission that they became debased. We must be cautious in advocating a royal commission as they can be catastrophically expensive. Just look at the cost of the HIH royal commission, let alone the building industry one. The biggest weakness of royal commissions is also their strength—they operate on the basis of lesser standards of evidence than courts or other judicial inquiries. This allows them to get a much wider range of views. But, on a delicate subject such as paedophilia, hearsay evidence can unjustly destroy reputations. It is essential that counsel assisting carefully sift potential evidence before calling it before a royal commission. I do not have time to list the various abuses committed by royal commissions over the last few decades in terms of hearsay evidence. Most senators would be aware of them and most senators would not approve of them.

In assessing the issues surrounding the fate of the Governor-General, the opposition will always be accused of partisanship. For the record, I have never met or had any dealings with Dr Hollingworth. I did not oppose his appointment. But there is no doubt in my mind that his credibility to hold a high office has been mortally wounded. Given all that has happened, I hope the Governor-General takes into account item (2)(b) of this motion and resigns forthwith, if only to uphold the esteem of the office he now holds.

talk.start.para: —I commend the speech by Senator Ray. It was a most positive contribution to a very difficult debate. It outlined very cogently some of the difficult matters that we have all had to consider before this motion came before the Senate and that we will have to consider in deciding whether or not to support it. The Greens will be supporting the motion. It urges the Prime Minister to establish a royal commission into child sexual abuse in Australia. Secondly, it urges the Governor-General to immediately resign or, if he does not do so, requests that the Prime Minister advise the Queen of Australia to terminate the commission of the Governor-General. We are at the moment in an unprecedented and terrible situation as far as the governor-generalship is concerned. No motion such as this has ever come before the Senate. It cannot be and is not being taken lightly and a lot of consideration has gone into it.

speech.para: I want to deal with each of the sections of the motion. The first is that the Governor-General should immediately resign or, if he does not, the Prime Minister should terminate his commission. This matter cannot be confined to narrow legal or even political matters. It is to do with the office itself, which should be unifying, celebratory and beyond controversy for this nation. The Governor-General is not elected and cannot be dis-appointed by the people of Australia. It is a decision, as we have heard, made by the executive, and on this occasion made solely by the Prime Minister without reference to others. Therefore it is logically a matter for the Prime Minister to consider when the Senate calls for that commission to be terminated. I noted in Senator Faulkner's speech the remarkable quote from 15 months ago when the Prime Minister, when questioned about that appointment, said:
... of course I did not ask Archbishop Hollingworth whether there was something.
He also said that he did not send him a form to fill out. The Prime Minister might quite rightly be asked, `Why did you not ask him?'

talk.start.para: —As Senator Murray says, he does that for ministers and sets out requirements for ministers. But the responsible question for any potential contender for the position of Governor-General ought to have been—as it is routinely for any appointment to any job if it is responsibly done, and none more importantly than to the highest position in the land—`Is there anything that you know about which would make difficult or obviate your appointment to this position?' But the Prime Minister did not do that. Then the course of events we are all so familiar with took place. In particular, the diocesan board of the Anglican Church in Queensland found that the Governor-General's behaviour during his period as Archbishop of Brisbane had been untenable. This related to a direct request to Dr Hollingworth from victims of sexual abuse to have action taken on their behalf. That request was not responded to in the way it should have been. Senator Murray indicated by interjection that it should have been a matter put into the hands of the police, and I agree with that. The difficulty has come from that situation and other matters that members have brought up.

speech.para: The fact is the Governor-General ought to have stood down from his position when these matters first came to the fore and certainly when that diocesan commission made its findings. But there is a tendency now to bring in legal and public relations assistance and to tough it out. One cannot fail to commiserate with His Excellency the Right Reverend Peter Hollingworth and his family for the torment they must be going through at this time. But as other speakers have said, the office is beyond that. It is for the Governor-General to step down in defence of the office and the rights of 20 million Australians to believe that that office is beyond the conjecture and controversy now surrounding it. The obvious question is: how many people have been and are suffering simply because of this controversy, because they have been victims and even perpetrators in the scourge of paedophilia in our society?

That brings me to the second point of the motion, which is the establishment of a royal commission. The question here is for the Prime Minister. The request is being made to the Prime Minister, because the Senate cannot of itself establish such a royal commission. There will be some debate about whether that would become a witch-hunt or not. I would counsel very strongly that the major direction for a royal commission, and the major term of reference to a royal commission, would be to find those ways of best ameliorating, minimising and preventing child abuse in the future while bringing succour and help to people who have been victims and perpetrators of paedophilia in the past. Royal commissions can do that. I believe there should be a national royal commission.

The argument from Senator Hill was that it was a state matter. I do not believe that is the case. At the moment we have different laws in different states. In an interview with a radio station in Western Australia today I was acquainted with the fact that there is no requirement for mandatory reporting of paedophilia in that state. I understand that it is not universal elsewhere in Australia either. I remember, as a young doctor, when that was first mooted for the medical profession way back in the seventies or eighties. It was hugely contentious that there should be intervention between the client and the doctor. But let me say it has been hugely important for both that the client's best interests are protected and the matter is brought to the surface because, firstly, it has the flow-on effect of protecting others in the future and, secondly, the terrible decision is taken off the shoulders of the medical practitioner, the teacher or the other responsible person as to whether or not they should inform the police. To do so would have the ramifications that are argued about—that is, unsettling family, causing public odium and getting out of hand. It is important that mandatory reporting be part of the suite of measures taken to reduce and eliminate paedophilia, which is so damaging to young people. But even that needs to be understood as always having an impact on both victim and perpetrator which can be extremely damaging. There has to be very deft and experienced handling of that.

There is a wealth of experience in our community. Let it be brought together. Let it be canvassed and analysed. If something good is to come out of this terrible set of circumstances, let it be a new national direction to prevent the sexual abuse of children in our great nation in the future. I think all of us are concerned that the matter should go before a royal commission, with the extraordinary powers that it has. My concern is that if it does not go to such an inquiry we will not take this opportunity to reassess where we are and to minimise harm to not tens, dozens, scores or hundreds but thousands of children who are at this moment trapped in circumstances where they are being taken advantage of by an adult, most often in the home. Let us not forget that. Let us find measures to help overcome the difficulties which come from the secrecy, the sense of shame and the power of adults to frighten the young into submission and secrecy against their own interests and in a way which traumatises them for the rest of their lives. We have to do more about that. I believe we have the information to do it, but we have to find better ways of ensuring that no child is beyond the reach of the best help that is available.

I support the motion and appeal to the Prime Minister to consider both parts of the active components of this motion. Ultimately, a very great responsibility is on Prime Minister Howard to give effect to this motion, whether or not it passes the Senate. He has an enormous responsibility to reconsider the position of Governor-General Hollingworth, who was, after all, appointed at his sole behest. He has a huge deal of thinking to do about what we as a nation can do to minimise absolutely the damage done to young people—and therefore to people all their lives—through abuse, which is unwanted and damaging to children. I believe that, if there is a better option to a royal commission, to draw all the strings together and to find the best answers, it is incumbent upon those who oppose it to come up with that option. As it is, I join the appeal to the Prime Minister to take that option for us—in terms of a royal commission—to go through what will be a travail, as well as, hopefully, by the end of it, an enlightening and positive process for the nation.

talk.start.para: —As the chamber knows, I do not come to this debate as a novice, in that I have now been on a five-year campaign in relation to issues of child abuse and the consequences of it. Despite my institutional background, which the chamber is also aware of, I was not really acquainted with more than a general knowledge in these areas. It is only by my exposure through the Senate and various inquiries that I have come to the fairly deep understanding that I now have. I regret sincerely having to get involved in many of the issues that I have, simply because of the horrible stuff you have to read and the horrible circumstances you have to live through when, as a consequence of their experiences, adults, some of them grandparents, tremble and weep in your office. It is not something that will ever leave me.

speech.para: I want to commence by making some remarks about the government record in this general area, and in doing so I am not going to reflect on individuals in the coalition, because many of those individuals in the coalition that I have talked to have been deeply moved on, and are deeply concerned about, this issue. I have had people at the highest levels weep with me. So these remarks do not reflect on all. Nevertheless, governments as a body have to be accountable.

In the last five years this government has vigorously opposed the child migrant inquiry. It never facilitated and was extremely lukewarm about the third inquiry, which is now before us, in the trilogy, inquiring into institutionalised Australian children in the last century. It has been defensive on the stolen generation. With respect to one of the recommendations of the child migrant inquires, it has refused to petition the Queen to knock the infamous Brother Keaney off the honours list, despite leading a paedophile ring in one of the worst annals of child abuse in this country—and that was a unanimous recommendation by all parties.

The coalition have a record of being harsh on children in detention. They have a very recent record of being delinquent in addressing the trafficking in women and the prosecutions that should arise from that. Having themselves initiated some groundbreaking law, they did not provide the means to prosecute those laws. I have no obvious memory in my mind of them being any good in this area, of having any programs to address this child abuse area. I think they have had programs to address rape and violence in the home, but with the broader issue of child abuse they have simply passed the buck.

My message to the coalition is this: it is no good being men of steel in war but marshmallow men in matters of child abuse; it is no good having lots of ticker but being seen as having no heart; it is no good being tough on crime but soft on child abuse. In the face of massive national concern on this issue—and it is massive, because many thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, are affected—this government has shown no leadership. Frankly, I think it should. Those individuals amongst the government who are concerned in this area need to carry the torch a little stronger.

Much has been made of the fact that these events occurred before the Governor-General came to office, but his conduct on these matters while in office has been poor. That is best exhibited by his performance on Australian Story which exposed terrible judgment and a terrible lack of sensitivity. For somebody who is a former social worker, and is therefore trained in and understands these issues, that is a very poor attitude. His evidence to the church inquiry exposes him in a serious manner. But, more importantly, if you have conducted yourself before you reach office in such a way as requires you to resign from that office, you would have to do so. A number of speakers, including most recently Senator Brown, have made clear their view that you should be properly checked for any high office. If the Prime Minister was discovered to have concealed a major crime in a previous life, the whole parliament would demand that he remove himself, and quite properly so.
I will quote briefly from pages 48 and 49 of the report. It states:
Dr Hollingworth, through his solicitors, has contended that he based that decision upon his understanding that the sexual abuse was an isolated occurrence.
I remind you that this is a social worker; I think he would know different. It goes on:
The complainant on the other hand contends that he told Dr Hollingworth the details of the abuse, and that it involved repeated criminal acts.
The very essence of paedophilia is that it is repetitive. Senator Brown, as a doctor, has indicated his knowledge of that. It then states:
The Board finds that Dr Hollingworth's recollections are faulty, and that he has apparently reconstructed what he believed he was told, rather than recalled what in fact was said.
You could be much stronger in your language but we all know what that implies. It goes on:
The board considers that no bishop acting reasonably could have reached the decision to continue a known paedophile in the ministry—
because they will repeat the crime. I want you to contemplate the crime.

Moving on from those brief quotes from the report, the Governor-General has confounded many of us by clinging to his office in the face of huge public dismay. Quite frankly, any person in public office knows that you have to resist the baying of the mob, but this is the expression of public opinion as a result of a revulsion at the way issues were handled. If the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition, the President of the Senate or the Speaker—or I—had to deal similarly with issues of this sort, I think we would be gone pretty quickly. Why? Because we are accountable. The difficulty with the Governor-General's office is that he is not accountable; he just needs the support of one man—and even then that man, the Prime Minister, can be defied.

The Democrats, Labor and many others have called for the Governor-General to resign. He can of course resign of his own volition. Either privately or publicly, the Prime Minister could request him to resign; he could defy that, although you would expect him not to. If he refused to resign, the Prime Minister could petition the Queen to remove him and she would undoubtedly do so in those circumstances. There is no provision for impeachment. The parliament of Australia has no powers either of appointment or dismissal. The house of the executive, which is the House of Representatives, will not take action if the Prime Minister does not want it. The Senate, as it is doing now, can pass a powerful but powerless symbolic motion of no-confidence or a motion of condemnation.

The one action we can take is to go directly to the Queen using the device of an address to the Queen. I think that would produce a fascinating constitutional situation as to whether the Queen would feel obliged to reject or accept the Senate's view in the face of prime ministerial support. Neither I nor anyone else has yet contemplated that the Senate do so, because we hope that good sense will prevail and the Governor-General will understand he must go.

For the public, the issue is huge. There are not many things that get people quite as angry as the sexual assault of children. Note that I and the members of my party consistently use the words `sexual assault'. It is a criminal act. It is not abuse; it is assault. And that it is of children is abominable. Put bluntly, for Peter Hollingworth—the Governor-General now, the archbishop then—the general case that has been made is this: the sexual assault of children is a crime. As archbishop, he was the head of an organisation that did not report such crimes to the police or statutory authorities. The organisation protected the criminals responsible by concealing the crimes and, through retention or promotion, gave such criminals further opportunities to access further victims.

In a number of the cases that have been exposed, the archbishop was apprised of the circumstances, acted with the executive authority and determined the course of action. The cases covered by the church board of inquiry set up by the diocese of Brisbane do not include some exposed in the media, further cases before the courts or cases that complainants did not put before it but will pursue elsewhere. For instance, the diocese is reported to be dealing with 157 cases. In other words, there may well be more to come that concern the Governor-General. Just to remind senators of that quote from the board's findings:
The Board considers that no Bishop acting reasonably could have reached the decision to continue a known paedophile in the ministry.

The public do not think the constitutional consequence of the Governor-General resigning more important than being rid of someone that they believe is unsuited as a result of those actions and events precedent and subsequent to his high office. The public at large do not think Archbishop Hollingworth's conduct was a blemish, as I have heard it described, or a simple error of judgment; they think it was a disgrace. In my view, the archbishop does not have the judgment or character required for someone in the office of Governor-General, and he should go.

Writing more generally of church behaviour concerning child abuse and to put the matter in a little more perspective, in an article titled `Church needs the law of man' in the Age on 6 June 2002 Dr Chris Goddard, the Director of the Child Abuse and Family Violence Research Unit at Monash University, said the following:

There appear to be many opportunities for the full force of the criminal law to be brought to bear upon those in positions of power who have not taken reasonable steps to protect children. Surely, the bishop who has transferred from one parish to another a priest who is the subject of complaints has failed in his duty of care to the children of the next parish? Aiding and abetting, being an accessory after the fact, obstructing the administration of justice, compounding a felony, even criminal conspiracy, are crimes that would spring to mind if it were drug dealing or car theft that we were concerned about.

There have been questions as to why there should be a royal commission. An inquiry into the scale of the sexual assault of children and the concealment of crimes within churches or other institutions could only ever be successfully pursued through a royal commission because of the powers attached and to issue warrants, pursue discovery and initiate a thorough investigation. A royal commission is ordinarily appointed when there is no other way to deal with a major social problem and there is widespread national concern.

The fact is that a royal commission has investigative powers. As has been discovered in America, only when you can get into the filing cabinet and get people to give you the information or disclosure that is necessary are you able to establish the scale and nature of the problem. The scale of the problem is not understood by politicians and policy makers in general, which is a question of ignorance and not of malice. Until they understand the scale of the abuse and sexual assault of children, they will not be able to move from perceiving it as an occasional occurrence requiring criminal charges and perhaps a social work remedy to seeing it as a problem with huge social and economic costs that requires significant government and other programs to address it. That is why it is a national issue. That is why this government should take the lead. You cannot ask six state royal commissions to be set up—what a ludicrous idea. You have to have the means to measure this nationally. It is not an issue principally of the past, because its knock-on consequences affect another 40 to 50 years of adult life and can affect the children—that is, the third generation—as well, because of the effects on people's emotional, mental and physical states.

Then there is the question of concealment. We are talking about criminal conspiracy for the large scale protection of paedophiles by church and other institutions—not by a majority; of course not. The majority of priests and the religious are not part of this, but a minority are, and they have had terrible effects on our society and other societies. The Australian experience is similar, and it is no accident that most of these complaints are from within churches. Just think: 157 in the Brisbane diocese alone have come to the surface. Just try to work out all the other dioceses and churches that are involved. They settle these claims confidentially to protect their money and to protect the institution. The victim comes last. The problem is that for governments the social and economic costs are so major that, unless you attend to those costs, you will not realise the problems that you are not facing up to and their effects on society. So my view is that only once the scale and the nature of the problem have been properly exposed can you deal with the remedies and policy changes that are necessary.

Obviously, the terms of reference for any royal commission would need to be carefully developed in consultation with advocates, experts and campaigners in this area. I concur with Senator Ray that the rules of evidence should be extremely carefully set for such a royal commission. You have to be very careful about people's reputations and these matters, but you cannot squib on this issue and its scale. When I heard that the Prime Minister—and I hope I am not misquoting him—had stated that he would prefer to spend $60 million on services rather than line the pockets of lawyers by way of a royal commission, I was absolutely shocked at the insensitivity and the priorities that that indicated. Somebody who can spend $60 million on the Cole royal commission and then say, `You can't spend $60 million on an inquiry into child abuse,' exhibits an attitude that the Australian people will punish this government for. It does not matter what party or what age group they come from; they will not put up with a government that has not realised it must put children first.

The consequences of the actions of the Governor-General when he was archbishop, or others who have allowed paedophiles to continue, need to be understood—and the scale needs to be understood. I sometimes remind people that the figures we have indicate that up to 10,000 child migrants, 40,000 Aboriginal children and as many as 100,000 non-Indigenous Australian children were institutionalised last century—that is up to 200,000 children, many of whom were abused. That is just in the institutions, never mind the boarding schools and all the other places where these things went on. So, literally millions of Australians have interactions with the hundreds of thousands who have been exposed to a variety of abuses, from emotional deprivation all the way through to sexual assault.

Let me give you an idea of what happens when you let paedophiles abuse people. There is a knock-on consequence—80 to 85 per cent of women in Australian prisons have been victims of incest or other forms of abuse, according to an article in the Alternative Law Journal in 1994; another Australian study of 27 correctional centres in New South Wales found that 65 per cent of male and female prisoners were victims of child sexual and physical assault; the New South Wales Child Protection Council reported in 1992 that the probability of future delinquency, adult criminality and arrest for a violent crime increased by around 40 per cent for people assaulted and neglected as children.

Institutionalised children or people subject to abuse indulge in substance abuse—44 per cent of fire injuries have been found to be associated with alcohol. In Ireland they found that, of people who had suffered this abuse, 14 per cent ended up as prostitutes; 68 per cent ended up needing health board care and experienced homelessness; 66 per cent of those who left their special schools and had been abused ended up in prison or in other places of detention within three years. You cannot underestimate, when dealing with these issues, what the consequences are of letting a paedophile priest continue to practice. I would urge this government, firstly, to dismiss the Governor-General and, secondly, to institute a royal commission into sexual abuse.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray has just made a very impassioned speech. This is a subject that he has spent a lot of time and a lot of effort on. We are all familiar with his background as a migrant from the UK. What he says in regard to paedophilia—abused children—is absolutely correct. No-one on this side of the Senate would not support him on those views. Everyone, on any side of politics, would be totally opposed to any form of paedophilia.

speech.para: But we are not debating paedophilia tonight. The opposition and the minor parties have put forward a very general two-page motion that attacks the Prime Minister for his choice of Governor-General and goes right through to calling for a royal commission. The Prime Minister made a choice, an open choice, six years ago of an archbishop who had a background of welfare and community support over 30 years, who subsequently has done nothing while in the office of Governor-General to remove him from that office. He has not offended in any way while he has been Governor-General. In the last week or so, what I suppose you could call a red herring case concerning an allegation of rape has been introduced, which has clouded the issue.

I think we ought to stand back and look at where we are at. The Governor-General is not in office. He will not be taking part in any duties. Those duties have been accepted by and transferred to the Governor of Tasmania, who is the senior state governor and who will fulfil the role of the position of Governor-General. The Governor-General has said publicly that he will place the dignity and protection of the office of Governor-General above all other considerations when he makes a decision. He gave that commitment to the Prime Minister, and so I think the timing of this motion is wrong.

You have had the Governor-General make that commitment and you have had the Prime Minister intervene and talk to him. The Prime Minister intervened at the earliest opportunity that was available to him when he returned from overseas. The Prime Minister dealt with the issue as soon as he returned to Australia. At the weekend, he immediately addressed the issue and received from the Governor-General the commitment, and I repeat his words: `I will place the dignity and protection of the office above all other considerations.'

So I do not think anyone can accuse the Prime Minister of being tardy or not taking the right action. The Prime Minister was on the spot as soon as he could get back and address the issue that was before the people. The Governor-General has given the commitment that, in considering his long-term tenure in that office, he will place the dignity and protection of that office above all other considerations. The Prime Minister has taken a serious step. This has never occurred before in the history of Australia, and I would think that we are not likely to have this occur again—and I certainly hope that we do not.

It has been said, and this has been repeated by the press on a number of occasions, that only the Governor-General can make this decision. Only the Governor-General can balance his conscience against the needs of Australia, and I think that is what he is doing at the moment. The agony that Dr Hollingworth and his family must be going through at the moment has been acknowledged by a couple of speakers who I have listened to. That is part of the public process in Australia; it is a boots and all effort with the press, and if they can expose something they will. We do have a vigorous press.

The institution of Governor-General has to deal with something it has never had to deal with before, and I think is better for the Governor-General to make that decision. I do not think he is taking it lightly. I think he needs a bit of clear air to make it. I had hoped that we would not have a motion like this, which I think politicises the office of Governor-General. I know that politics is a rough-house in Australia and that the opposition believes it will gain some tactical advantage by trying to raise this issue and score some political points off it. I am reluctant to get involved in that.

It is unnecessary to demand that the Prime Minister sack the Governor-General, because I think the decision is going to be made. The present Governor-General has already indicated that he is prepared to step aside when he balances the equation of placing the dignity and protection of the office above all other considerations. He has taken the decision that he is not going to hurt the office. I believe the issue is being dealt with responsibly by the Prime Minister, within the correct parameters and procedures of our system and by means within the system that respect and reinforce the institutions of government.

If the opposition were serious about this motion that they are moving in the Senate and if it were a matter of fundamental belief to them—a matter of such importance—why wouldn't it be moved simultaneously in the Senate and the House of Representatives? If it is a matter of high importance, it should be moved in both houses—in the house of the people and in the house of review.

This is an effort to embarrass the government—that is what oppositions are there to do. But there is more to this than embarrassing the government. We have a Constitution and we have a set of rules of government. Australia voted almost overwhelmingly—not quite overwhelmingly in some states, but overwhelmingly in others—that they wanted the present means of government, the constitutional monarchy, to stay in place. A referendum was held, the matter of a republic was put to the referendum and people supported the present system. By moving this motion—and I do not think it had to be moved; I think it will resolve itself—we place the institutions of Governor-General, the parliament and the division of powers between the judiciary and the parliament into a big melting pot and we do not know what will happen.

As a father and a grandfather, I cannot speak strongly enough against interference with children. Nothing makes me shudder more. I think every government has to address it. The real problem is that the state governments are in charge of social welfare, community services and education; about all of the areas where paedophilia is rampant, apart from in homes, are public institutions, and all of those public institutions are virtually controlled by the state governments. Criminal law, health, education and child welfare are all responsibilities of the state governments. It is not an issue that this government is directly responsible for. Our role in the political field is to implement policies that are in the best interests of Australia—to set budgets, as we will be doing tonight, and put down parameters. But the minutiae of government is really controlled by the state governments. I am not sure that the state governments want this. Mr Beattie, the Premier of Queensland, has called for one, but the Premier of New South Wales has not supported one, so there seems to be some division there.

The Prime Minister has acted as soon as possible to fix this very severe problem. He made a judgment of his candidate for Governor-General, and he based it on 30 years of public exposure. He based it on goodwill. The Governor-General himself accepts that he had a serious conflict in judgment. Therefore I think that we should accept the commitment that the Governor-General has given to the press and to the Prime Minister that he will examine his own conscience and will not allow the office of Governor-General to be denigrated. I believe the issue will be resolved in the not too distant future.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by Senator Faulkner in respect of the office of Governor-General. There is no doubt in my mind, or in the minds of the Australian people, in my view, that the Governor-General should have taken the right decision and resigned. Regardless of the outcome of the case revealed by the lifting of the suppression order by the Supreme Court of Victoria, it is clear, at least to me, that a profound human tragedy has in fact occurred.

speech.para: The Governor-General, although stood aside, like all Australians is entitled to the presumption of innocence. The rape allegations brought to light over the past week are completely separate from the arguments that warrant the Governor-General resigning. In the absence of that happening, the Governor-General being dismissed by the Prime Minister is the next logical step that should be taken. It is no longer tenable for him to hold the position. I make no comment in respect of the court case that is presently on foot. It is not a matter that should be canvassed here at this time. My views were informed prior to that issue having been reported in the media.

The Governor-General should personify the conscience of the nation by showing sensitivity towards those in need. He could take a leaf out of the book of our previous Governor-General, Sir William Deane, who had the ability to represent all members of the community. His tenure as Governor-General was more in the role of a national moral guardianship, with the promotion of core moral values, for which Australians admired and respected him. Did Sir William Deane set the standard too high during his time as Governor-General? I do not believe he did. The media espoused his qualities, qualities that we have yet to see from the person currently appointed to the position. Sir William worked to bring public awareness to the plight of Australians in hardship. He was a true representative of the Australian people. He will long be remembered.

In contrast, it was said when Dr Hollingworth was first flagged as our Governor-General that it would be impossible for him to separate the church from the state and that his position as the representative of the Australian people to the Queen would be compromised by a lifetime of beliefs he had learnt and taught within the church. But it was also said that he was a tireless advocate for our underprivileged people, that his integrity was unquestionable and that a lifetime of service to the public would stand him in good stead with all Australians. I understand there were, however, rumblings by senior Anglicans, who saw the conflict for an ordained priest and consecrated bishop who held key positions within the church. Dr Hollingworth promised to place the dignity and protection of the office of Governor-General above all else. In truth, he has put at risk the office losing the respect of the Australian people. If his promise were true, he should have resigned when the allegations and, subsequently, the truth came out in December 2001.

The Prime Minister should have addressed the Governor-General on this issue when it was first raised. In my view, the Prime Minister has failed in his duty to the Australian people to ensure that the office of the Governor-General is not tarnished by scandal. The current controversy should be ended quickly, and the office of the Governor-General may be spared any further damage. It is in the hands of the Governor-General to resign or of the Prime Minister to demand his resignation. Dr Hollingworth must resign, because of his proven failure to appropriately deal with child sexual abuse and for his protection of an admitted paedophile.

The Anglican Church report was critical of Dr Hollingworth's handling of allegations of numerous cases of child sex abuse by members of the clergy whilst he was in charge of the Brisbane diocese. I underscore the point that the findings have been reached after lengthy investigation by an independent board of inquiry consisting of individuals of the highest reputation. I have no reason to doubt the board's fairness and impartiality. The Anglican Church inquiry report into victims of child sex abuse by the Anglican Church found that Dr Hollingworth failed to act against a known paedophile and that his actions were untenable. The board's report does contain criticism of Dr Hollingworth in respect of the handling of the Elliot matter. After weighing the information available to it, including submissions from Dr Hollingworth's solicitors—parts of which are reproduced in the report—the board said in section 15.8:

The Board considers that no Bishop acting reasonably could have reached the decision to continue a known paedophile in the ministry. There were no extenuating circumstances nor can the Board imagine any that could have justified his continuance.
At 15.9, on page 49 of the report, the board found:

Dr Hollingworth's decision, whilst made in good faith, and in consultation, and without demur of the bishops whom he consulted, and in the belief that precautionary conditions imposed minimised the risk of recurrence, was untenable.
In his media release, Archbishop Aspinall said:

... I believe it is incumbent on me as Archbishop to express my firm view that to allow Elliot to continue in office, following his admission of child sexual abuse, was a serious error of judgment. I take this view without expressing an opinion about whether or not the child sexual abuse was understood to be a long-past, isolated incident.

These comments were not easy for Archbishop Aspinall to make. In fact, he points out during his media statement his affection for Dr and Mrs Hollingworth. The Archbishop had a duty to inform the public and the parliament of the outcomes of the inquiry. It was not a witch-hunt against Dr Hollingworth but, rather, a truthful account of the shortcomings and short-sightedness of our Governor-General. On a third avenue of inquiry, regarding Bishop Shearman, Professor Briggs of the inquiry considered:

... that once Dr Hollingworth in his capacity as Archbishop was apprised of the serious misconduct of the Respondent, he should, in order to demonstrate proper moral leadership, have withdrawn the permission. Professor Briggs considers that in the circumstances Dr Hollingworth's failure to do so was inappropriate.

That can be found at 13.10, or pages 40 to 41, of the inquiry report. These were damning comments, to my mind. Why would the Prime Minister not demand in the face of that that the Governor-General tender his resignation? Why has the Prime Minister not acted since the release of the report to remove the Governor-General from office? How far does this government intend to let slide the good work previously attributed to the office of the Governor-General before it acts? The Prime Minister not only should act but must act. This is not about finding guilt, although it is around; it is about a government that is unwilling to take the morally correct steps to retain some dignity in one of our highest offices. For more than two years the public has listened in disbelief to the revelations as they have come to light. Now, with the release of the report, perhaps the victims and the church may be able to find a way to move forward. For more than two years our Prime Minister has hedged on the issue of retaining dignity and integrity within the office of the Governor-General. It is a simple matter. Why cannot our Prime Minister see that there is no option other than to demand the resignation of the Governor-General and end what some refer to as a constitutional crisis but what is in fact a crisis in the Prime Minister's own mind? Why did the Prime Minister refuse at first to table the report?
Debate interrupted.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.
