Finally, members are appointed on either a part-time or full-time basis, as noted in the table, and the number of days that part-time members are engaged varies according to their availability and the Tribunal's case load.

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: Nursing Home Type Patients
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1240)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the current number of nursing home type patients in public hospitals; (b) what is the breakdown of this number by state; and (c) what is the median and average length of stay after classification as a nursing home patient before the patient leaves the hospital.

(2) What is the current number of nursing home type patients in private hospitals; (b) what is the breakdown of this number by state; and (c) what is the median and average length of stay after classification as a nursing home patient before the patient leaves the hospital.

(3) Of the 121 divisions of general practice, how many have on their boards of directors: (a) an allied health professional; (b) a non-medical practitioner hospital representative; (c) a non-medical practitioner community health representative; and (d) a consumer organisation representative.

(4) Of the state-based organisations for divisions of general practice, how many have on their boards of directors: (a) an allied health professional; (b) a non-medical practitioner hospital representative; (c) a non-medical practitioner community health representative; and (d) a consumer organisation representative.

(5) What is the professional representation of the board of the Australian Divisions of General Practice (ADGP); and (b) and does it include: (i) an allied health professional, (ii) a non-medical practitioner hospital representative, (iii) a non-medical practitioner community health representative, and (iv) a consumer organisation representative.
(6) Are there other decision-making bodies (i.e. not advisory bodies) within the structure of the divisions and ADGP; if so, what is the professional representation on these bodies.

(7) For each of the following financial years: 2000-01 and 2001-02, and for the 2002-03 financial year to date, what sums of Commonwealth money have been allocated under the More Allied Health Services (MAHS) program and to which divisions.
(8) In how many cases in each of the above time periods has Commonwealth money under the MAHS program been allocated to practices or to medical practitioners for a practice nurse.
(9) In each case, what was the MAHS funding amount allocated for the services of a practice nurse.
(10) Was the practice nurse in each of these cases salaried; if so, in each case what was the (pro-rated) annual salary; if not, in each case what was the funding arrangement for the nurse.

(11) Of the practice nurses funded through MAHS, in how many cases did the funding go to a practice which, or a practitioner who, did not actually increase the number of nurse positions (i.e. funding went to an existing nurse).
(12) In how many instances where a practice nurse was funded through MAHS was there a formal consultation process by the division with community representatives, canvassing community needs.

(13) In how many instances where a practice nurse was funded through MAHS was there a report of the consultation process by the division with community representatives, canvassing community needs of health services.

(14) (a) Which body has the decision-making power to allocate funds under MAHS; and (b) is this body required to take into account a community needs assessment in determining MAHS funding: if not, why not.
(15) In how many divisions where other allied health services were funded through MAHS was there a formal consultation process by the division, canvassing community needs of health services.

(16) In how many instances where other allied health services were funded through MAHS was there a report of the consultation process by the division with community representatives, canvassing community needs of health services.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)-(2) A Nursing Home Type Patient (NHTP) is a patient who has been in hospital (public and/or private) for a continuous period exceeding 35 days and does not have a current acute care certificate issued under section 3B of the Health Insurance Act 1973 (Cwlth).

Under the 1998-2003 Australian Health Care Agreements there is no State and Territory data collected by the Commonwealth which identifies the current number of NHTPs or the median and average length of stay after patients have been classified as NHTPs.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has not reported NHTPs since 1998-99 due to inconsistency in reporting between jurisdictions. The Institute also concluded that NHTP is essentially a payment category rather than a type of care.

(3) The Department collects data from Divisions via an Annual Survey of Divisions undertaken by the Primary Health Care Research and Information Service (PHCRIS). Data collected in the Annual Survey of Divisions for 2001-02 (yet to be published) indicates that 43 Divisions (35%) out of the then 123 Divisions had a total of 74 non-GPs on their boards.
The following table provides a breakdown of the non-GP board positions reported by Divisions:
* The total number of this column is more than 43 because some Divisions had more than one non-GP on their boards.

· Divisions were asked in the Survey to nominate the types of non-GPs on their boards, but not according to a given set of categories such as those used in this Question on Notice. For example, as the Survey did not specifically ask about the representation of allied health professionals on boards, these professionals could be included in the “Division CEO/EO/staff” category as well as the “total health sector” category.
· The Survey did not identify how many of the 29 consumers on boards were drawn from consumer organisations.
(4) There are seven State-Based Organisations (SBOs) for Divisions of General Practice (in the ACT, the Division and SBO form one body). The boards of SBOs mainly consist of GPs.

In addition, there is a consumer representative on the boards of two SBOs. One SBO has an indigenous representative on its board. There is a State Health Department representative on the board of one SBO. SBO staff (usually the CEO) are represented on the boards of three SBOs.
(5) The ADGP Board comprises 14 GPs, drawn from each State and Territory, plus a representative from a consumer organisation.
(6) The boards of individual Divisions, State-Based Organisations and the ADGP are the primary decision-making bodies within these organisations.
(7) The following table contains the allocations under the More Allied Health Services (MAHS) Program for the financial years 2000-01, 2001-02, and 2002-03:
The following table provides a list of Divisions that are receiving MAHS Program funding.

answer.para: (8) Information on the number of cases in the above time periods where Commonwealth funding under the MAHS Program has been allocated to practices or to medical practitioners specifically for a practice nurse is not collected.

In order to monitor the implementation of the MAHS Program, the Department of Health and Ageing has collected biannual snapshots of the type and estimated number of full time equivalent (FTE) allied health professionals funded under the Program on a particular date.
Information concerning the number of FTE registered nurses from the October 2001, April 2002 and October 2002 snapshots is provided in the table below:

entry.para: Registered Nurse - Diabetes EducatorRegistered Nurse - Mental HealthRegistered Nurse - Asthma Educator Registered Nurse - Other

answer.para: Practice nurses who may have been funded under the MAHS Program and who are not undertaking specialised roles would be included within the category of “Registered Nurse - Other”.
(9) This information is not collected.
(10) This information is not collected.
(11) This information is not collected.

The MAHS Program Guidelines state that the MAHS Program is not an alternative funding option for the employment of existing services or professionals in locations where services are currently provided.

In January 2002, the Department provided advice to all MAHS-eligible Divisions regarding the 2001 Practice Nurses Federal Budget initiative. Divisions were advised to ensure their MAHS activity did not allow for double payment for the employment of practice nurses.

(12) All MAHS-eligible Divisions (listed in question (7)) undertook a planning process in developing their original MAHS Program funding proposals. Planning processes under the MAHS Program Guidelines included community consultation and a needs assessment.
Divisions were expected to undertake discussions with a broad range of key community stakeholder groups, such as:
· General practitioners in eligible rural locations;
· Existing allied health service providers;
· Coordinators of existing/planned Commonwealth, state/territory and local government health initiatives;
· Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health services and advisory mechanisms; and
· Consumer representatives from eligible rural locations.
(13) All MAHS-eligible Divisions (listed in question (7)) were required to document evidence of community consultation.
Divisions' original MAHS Program funding proposals included a needs assessment in which Divisions outlined reasons for the selection of the proposed activities.

(14) (a) State and Territory offices of the Department of Health and Ageing have the decision-making power to allocate funds under the MAHS Program, in accordance with the requirements of the MAHS Program Guidelines that were approved by the Minister.

(b) In approving the provision of MAHS funding to a Division, the State and Territory offices of the Department are required to take into account the needs assessment submitted by each eligible Division.
(15) See response to (12).
(16) See response to (13).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

question.para: If the Western Australian State Government does not reform its current retail trading hours regulations, exactly what portion of the $75 million of ongoing annual competition payments from the National Competition Council will be withheld.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government will announce the level of competition payments to States and Territories following its consideration of the National Competition Council's assessment of jurisdictions' progress with implementing National Competition Policy and related reforms after it is received in mid-2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 6 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the number of students enrolled in James Cook University in postgraduate and undergraduate degrees be provided, by faculty and campus, for each of the past 10 years in equivalent full-time student units.
(2) Can numbers of academic and administrative support staff numbers, by faculty and campus, be provided for each of the past 10 years in full-time equivalents.

(3) Has the Minister or the department had any meetings or correspondence with proponents of the Cairns International University or anyone else on their behalf; if so: (a) with whom has the Minister or department met; and (b) can the following be provided: (i) a list of meeting dates, (ii) a list of correspondence, and (iii) copies of any correspondence and the minutes of any discussions.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Actual student load (EFTSU) for all students at James Cook University by broad level of course and Academic Organisational Unit 1992 to 2000 is provided at Attachment A. Data is not collected at the campus level.

A separate table is provided for 2001 also at Attachment A as DEST introduced a new Field of Education classification to replace the previous Field of Study classification in that year. The change was made so that DEST's data collection is comparable with related Australian Bureau of Statistics collections.
(2) Full time equivalent staff by academic and non academic classifications by Academic Organisational Unit 1992 to 2000 are provided at Attachment B. Data is not collected at the campus level.

A separate table is provided for 2001 at also Attachment B as DEST introduced a new Field of Education classification to replace the previous Field of Study classification in that year. The change was made so that DEST's data collection is comparable with related Australian Bureau of Statistics collections.

(3) Senator McLucas might like to note that the Queensland Government is responsible for the establishment of new universities in Queensland. I understand that on 31 October 2002, the Queensland Minister for Education received a proposal from Cairns International University Pty Ltd for the establishment and recognition of `Cairns University' as a private university. The proposal is currently under consideration by the Queensland Minister of Education.

(a) I have met once with Mr David Wills a representative from Cairns International University Pty Ltd. My Department is not aware of any other meetings with proponents of Cairns International University Pty Ltd since it submitted its proposal to become a University to the Queensland Government on 31 October 2002. No correspondence has been received from Cairns International University Pty Ltd.
(ii) Not applicable.
(iii) There are no minutes of the 12 March 2003 meeting.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 7 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister confirm remarks made on the 7.30 Report recently, in which he suggested that the national radioactive waste repository proposed for South Australia might be sited in another state.
(2) What other state did the Minister have in mind.
(3) Does the Minister rule out locating the national radioactive waste repository at Dutson Downs in Gippsland, Victoria.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I have not suggested that the national radioactive waste repository proposed for South Australia be sited in another state. The national repository will be sited at one of three sites near Woomera in South Australia, subject to successful completion of the environmental assessment and licensing processes.
(2) I do not have another state in mind for the national repository.
(3) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 10 March 2003 :

question.para: (1) Since October 2001, what briefings has the department, or any of its agencies, provided to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on the imposition of the `snap-back' provision whereby Japan will impose an increased tariff on imported Australian beef.
(2) Were the briefings written or oral.
(3) In the case of oral briefings: (a) when did these briefings occur; (b) who attended each briefing; and (c) what records were kept of each briefing.
(4) If the advice was written, can a copy be provided.
(5) Since October 2001, what briefings has the department, or any of its agencies, provided to the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on the imposition of the snap-back.
(6) Were the briefings written or oral.
(7) In the case of oral briefings: (a) when did these briefings occur; (b) who attended each briefing; and (c) what records were kept of each briefing.
(8) If the advice was written, can a copy be provided.

(9) Since October 2001, what advice has the department, or any of its agencies, provided to members of the Australian beef industry, beef-producer peak bodies or beef exporters in relation to the snap-back.
(10) Was the advice written or oral.
(11) In the case of written advice, can a copy of the advice be provided.
(12) In the case of oral advice: (a) when was the advice given; and (b) was the advice delivered face to face or by telephone or some other means.
(13) In the case of face-to-face advice: (a) who attended each meeting; and (b) what records were kept of each meeting.
(14) In the case of advice delivered by telephone or by some other means: (a) when was this advice given; (b) to whom was this advice given; and (c) what records were kept of each briefing.

(15) Since October 2001, has the department, or any of its agencies, met with officials from the United States of America, Canada, or New Zealand with a view to acting in conjunction with these nations in attempting to prevent the imposition by Japan of the snap-back.

(16) (a) When were these meetings conducted; (b) where were these meetings conducted; (c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these meetings; (d) what specifically was discussed at each meeting; (e) what was the outcome of each meeting; and (f) what records were kept of each meeting.

(17) Since October 2001, has the Minister met with his counterparts from the United States of America, Canada, or New Zealand with a view to acting in conjunction with these nations in attempting to prevent the imposition by Japan of the snap-back.

(18) (a) When were these meetings conducted; (b) where were these meetings conducted; (c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these meetings; (d) what specifically was discussed at each meeting; (e) what was the outcome of each meeting; and (f) what records were kept of each meeting.

(19) Since October 2001, has the department, or any of its agencies, offered any briefing to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry which was not accepted; if so, what was the reason given by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

(20) Since October 2001, has the Minister offered any briefing to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry which was not accepted; if so, what was the reason given by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Briefing for the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on the imposition of the beef-snapback tariff is primarily a matter for the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Australia (AFFA).

The Australian Embassy in Tokyo provided Mr Truss and his accompanying delegation with an oral briefing at the Quint meeting in late July 2002 before his meeting with then Japanese Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Takebe. There is no record of the oral briefing.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is, of course, in regular and constant contact and coordination with AFFA on this matter.
(2) See answer to Question 1.
(3) See answer to Question 1.
(4) See answer to Question 1.

(5) The possibility of Japan's applying the beef-snapback tariff first became apparent in July 2002. Japan indicated to Australia at the end of July its intention to impose the tariff, if imports rose to the snapback-trigger level.

On 27 August, the department called a roundtable meeting to discuss the snapback issue. That meeting was attended by DFAT, AFFA, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and the New Zealand High Commission.

DFAT and AFFA have continued a close consultative process since that time. There have been several small meetings between agencies. Both agencies have regularly exchanged views on appropriate actions to address the snapback issue. Cabled reports from our Embassy in Tokyo and other relevant cabled reports have been provided to AFFA.

Senior officials from DFAT attended a roundtable discussion called by AFFA on 3 February to discuss objectives and logistics for a beef industry meeting chaired jointly by Mr Vaile and Mr Truss on 6 February.

The Embassy in Tokyo briefed AFFA officials (Greg Williamson and Roland Pittar) who were members of the Australian delegation to the annual Beef Negotiations in Tokyo, 16-19 December 2002. The Embassy also briefed AFFA Deputy Secretary Wonder on the snapback issue during a beef-industry delegation visit to Tokyo, supported by the Government, 6-7 March.

(6) The briefings and discussions between the department and AFFA have been mostly oral. Both agencies have also exchanged appropriate documents on the beef-snapback issue to ensure a consistent whole-of-government approach. The cabled reports from the Embassy in Tokyo and other relevant cables, which have been provided to AFFA, are in written form.

(7) Oral briefing occurred during the meeting dates indicated above. The 27 August roundtable meeting was attended by Mr Tim Crowe, Executive Officer, Japan Section DFAT; Mr Ian MacIntosh, Executive Officer, Agriculture and Food Branch, DFAT; Mr Bill Withers, Manager, Asia, APEC, Trade Strategy, AFFA; Mr Terry Sheals, Chief Commodity Analyst, ABARE; Ms Trish Gleeson, Program Manager, Agriculture, ABARE; Mr Des Pearson, Manager, Trade Development - Wool and Dairy, AFFA; Ms Elizabeth Phillips, Meat and Livestock, AFFA

The 3 February meeting was attended by Mr Peter Rowe, Assistant Secretary, North East Asia Branch DFAT; Mr Tim Crowe, Executive Officer, Japan Section DFAT; Mr George Mina, Director, Agricultural Policy and Negotiations Unit DFAT; Mr Greg Williamson, General Manager, Meat, Wool and Dairy AFFA; Mr Bill Withers AFFA; Mr Jim Paradice AFFA; Mr Peter Hall AFFA.
No formal record was made of these meetings.
Between meetings, DFAT and AFFA have been in close and regular consultation. There are no formal records of these consultations.
(8) See answer to Question 7.

(9) The department maintains a close and cooperative dialogue with beef-industry representatives, particularly Meat and Livestock Australia (MLA), and has provided industry representatives with regular updates on developments in the beef snap-back issue. During the period in question, the Department discussed snapback and other meat access issues with MLA and other industry representatives at meetings of the Red Meat Access Forum on 4 September and 4 December 2002. The Department discussed the issue with Cattle Council representatives on a number of occasions.

Regular meetings and discussions have also taken place between officials at our Embassy in Tokyo and the MLA Japan Regional Manager. The Embassy provided a briefing on snap-back issues to MLA members of the Australian delegation to the annual Beef Negotiations in Tokyo, 16-19 December 2002. The Embassy also briefed industry representatives on the snapback issue during a beef-industry delegation visit to Tokyo, supported by the Government, 6-7 March 2003.
Mr Vaile and Mr Truss, along with senior officials from DFAT and AFFA, met representatives of the Australian beef industry on 6 February 2003. The discussions include the snap-back issue.
(10) Advice was provided orally. We have not located any record of written advice to industry.
(11) See answer to Question 10.
(12) The department has been in regular contact with industry over an extended period of time. Most oral communication has been by telephone.

(13) Industry representatives at the Embassy briefing conducted during annual Beef Negotiations in Tokyo, 16-19 December, were Samantha Jamieson, MLA's Japan Regional Manager, and Peter Barnard, General Manager, Economic Planning and Market Services, MLA. Industry representatives at the Embassy briefing conducted during the beef-industry delegation visit to Tokyo, 6-7 March, were Lachie Hart, Alan Teys and Keith Adams.
A list of industry and departmental attendees at the 6 February meeting with Ministers is attached at Annex 1.
Formal records were not kept of these briefings.

(14) Discussions between the department and industry by telephone have occurred on a regular basis, on average weekly since August 2002. Most communication with MLA has been between Mr Tim Crowe, Executive Officer, Japan Section DFAT, and Ms Linda Wilson, Manager, Japan Market Analysis and Support MLA, and Dr Peter Barnard, General Manager, Economic Planning and Market Services MLA. Ms Alison Burrows, Assistant Secretary, Agriculture and Food Branch DFAT, has been in regular communication with industry, notably the Cattle Council. Mr Allen Grant, Minister-Counsellor Agriculture at the Australian Embassy in Tokyo, has been in contact with MLA's Japan Regional Manager, Samantha Jamieson. These are, however, not the only communications.
There are no formal records of these briefings.

(16) The department, including through its overseas missions in relevant capitals, has had regular contact with representatives from other countries affected by the imposition of the snapback tariff. Such meetings are part of the normal activities and costs associated with the work of the department.

In particular, the Australian Embassy in Tokyo has been in close contact with the US, Canadian and New Zealand Embassies there to discuss and coordinate our approach to the snapback issue. Discussions in Tokyo were held within the participants' Embassies. Discussions were recorded in cabled reports and email.
The following list details the meetings our Embassy staff held with staff from other missions:
Canadian/US officials at Quint 26 July 2002
Canadian/US attaches 2 August 2002
Agricultural attaches 21 August 2002
US, NZ, Canada attaches 4 September 2002
US, NZ, Canada attaches 20 September 2002
US, NZ, Canada attaches 15 November 2002
US, NZ, Canada attaches 20 November 2002
US attache 3 December 2002
US attache 6 December 2002
US attache, 13 December 2002
US attache 6 January 2003
US, NZ, Canada attaches 27 January 2003
US attache 29 January 2003
Heads of Mission/Agricultural attaches from Canada, US, NZ 3 February 2003
US, Canadian attaches 18 February 2003
US attache 3 March 2003
US attache 4 March 2003
US attache 6 March 2003
(18) Mr Vaile discussed beef snapback with his New Zealand counterpart during his (Mr Vaile's) visit to New Zealand, 29-30 August 2002.

Mr Vaile wrote to his counterparts in Canada, New Zealand and the United States on 7 February to outline Australian actions to date and encourage continuing efforts by counterparts to persuade the Japanese Government to suspend the snapback mechanism.
Mr Vaile spoke by telephone to US Trade Representative Bob Zoellick on 11 February, during which they discussed beef snapback and our approaches to the Japanese Government.

Mr Vaile encouraged his counterparts from Canada, New Zealand and the United States to raise the snapback issue during the WTO mini-Ministerial meeting in Tokyo, 14-16 February, which Mr Vaile and his colleagues attended.

These discussions, including those held overseas, were part of the normal activities and costs associated with Mr Vaile's responsibilities as Minister for Trade. There are no formal records of these discussions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 10 March 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Gene Technology Information Service operated by Biotechnology Australia, which reports to senior Cabinet ministers including the Minister for agriculture Fisheries and Forestry:
(1) When was the service established.

(2) For each financial year since its establishment: (a) what has been the total amount of funding expended by the Commonwealth on the service; and (b) what proportion of the total costs of running the service has been borne by the department.
(3) What is the budgeted expenditure for the 2002-03 financial year.
(4) What has been the actual expenditure to date for the 2002-03 financial year.
(5) Which output area within the department is responsible for the service.

(6) Can a breakdown of direct and indirect costs be provided for each financial year since the service was established, including: (a) staff costs; (b) infrastructure costs (including maintenance); (c) telephone costs; (d) departmental costs; and (e) and any other costs.
(7) How does the service deliver information to customers who make inquiries of it.
(8) If the answer to (7) includes by telephone, what is the telephone number.

(9) Where the service delivers information to people who make inquiries of it in ways other than by telephone: (a) what methods are used by the service; and (b) how much has been spent by the service on each method for each financial year since its establishment.
(10) For each financial year since its establishment, how many inquiries were received by the service.

(11) What is the average response time for an inquiry, that is, what is the average time between when a customer makes an inquiry of the service and when the inquiry is considered by service to be complete.
(12) What are the hours of operation of the service.
(13) Have the hours of operation, or other operational details, altered since it was established; if so, can details these of changes be provided.

(14) What are the top 10 categories of customer inquiry to the service for each of the financial years since its establishment, breaking those categories into those who identify themselves as primary producers and those who do not.
(15) What media have been used to advertise the service or in some other way communicate to the public in order to make them aware that the service exists and what the role of the service is.

(16) For each financial year since its establishment, what has been the expenditure on advertising and other means used to communicate to the public in order to make them aware that the service exists and what the role of the service is.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) 20 December 1999.
(b) 70% covered by department.
(a) $88,460.14 (GST included);
(b) 70% covered by department.
(a) $148,500.78 (GST included);
(b) 70% covered by department.
(a) $52,251.76 (up to January 2003 - GST included);
(b) 70% covered by department.
(3) Budgeted expenditure for 2002/2003 is $100,000.
(4) Actual expenditure for 2002/2003 is $52,251.76 (payment from July 2002 to January 2003 with GST included).
(5) Biotechnology Australia.
(6) Breakdown of costs:
ii infrastructure: not applicable
iii telephone: $1,848.25
iv departmental: $118,525.15

iii telephone: $1,700.41

2002/2003 (up to end January 2003):

iv departmental: $52,251.76
(7) The service is delivered by phone, email, fax, mail and “in person” at various public events.
(8) The telephone number is 1800 631 276.
(9) Methods used to deliver service:
Mail, email, fax and in person.
1999/2000: breakdown of cost across methods of delivery not available during trial period.
ii Email approximately $720 (in-kind from the University of Melbourne)

(10) Enquiries received:
(11) The GTIS procedure is to respond with information or mail out fact sheets within 24 hours.
More complex queries such as requests for speakers are responded to within a week.
(12) 9am to 5pm weekdays (Australian Eastern Standard Time).
(13) No changes to hours of operation.
(14) Top 10 categories of enquiries, in order of frequency:

a. 1999/2000 - (i) other, (ii) GM food, (iii) gene technology, (iv) food safety, (v) labelling, (vi) request for resources (pamphlets), (vii) protest, (viii) regulations, (iv) request for speaker, and, (x) not available.

(15) GTIS has raised awareness of its service by a number of means such as:

The freecall number is listed on Biotechnology Australia publications, promotional products and web site, with no extra cost incurred.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence: Pine Gap Joint Defence Facility
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1255)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 March 2003:

question.para: In relation to the employees working at the Joint Defence Facility, Pine Gap:

(1) Has there been any form of industrial action by any employees working at Pine Gap over the past 3 years; if so (a) which employees were involved in the action; (b) what reason was given for undertaking the action; and (c) what was the response to the action.

(2) Are the terms and conditions of employment for citizens of the United States of America (US) working at the Pine Gap different to the terms and conditions for: (a) Australian citizens; and (b) US citizens who are permanent residents of Australia, working there.
(3) If the terms and conditions of employment are different for these groups of people: (a) can details of these differences be provided; and (b) can an explanation for the differences be provided.
(4) Do US citizens working at Pine Gap pay the same rates of income tax as: (a) Australia citizens; and (b) US citizens who are permanent residents of Australia, working there.
(5) If different rates of income tax apply for these groups of people: (a) can details of these differences be provided; and (b) can an explanation for the differences be provided.
(6) Are there differential rates of pay for: (a) US citizens; (b) US citizens who are permanent residents of Australia; and (c) Australian citizens.
(7) If different rates of pay apply for these groups of people: (a) can details of the differences be provided; and (b) can an explanation for the differences be provided.
(8) In what currency are: (a) US citizens; (b) US citizen who are permanent residents of Australia; and (c) Australian citizens, working at Pine Gap paid (for example, in $US or $A).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(a) Contractor employees periodically appeal their dismissal. These cases have been handled in accordance with Australian industrial relations procedures. There is currently a group action in process involving some, but not all, Australians employed by Raytheon Corporation regarding compensation.
(b) To support the employees' claim for salary increases in a new Certified Agreement.

(c) An action to terminate the current Certified Agreement was brought to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, but the commission has declined to proceed. Press reports indicate the workers are considering filing a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission case. Negotiations between the Australian Raytheon employees and the contractor are continuing. No response by the facility has been required or taken. There has been no disruption to facility activities.
(2) (a) Yes.
(b) No.

(3) (a) Representatives of the Government of Australia and the United States (US) Government are not directly involved in these issues, which are considered a matter between the contractor and their individual employees. In general, US personnel of contractors are employed under US laws, terms and conditions, and Australian personnel of contractors are employed under Australian laws, terms and conditions.
(b) As discussed above, the contractor is charged with ensuring compliance with the applicable regulations and statutes applicable to all categories of staff they employ.

(4) (a) No. Section 9 of the Agreement between the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of the United States of America relating to the establishment of a Joint Defence Space and Research Facility covers tax matters; essentially, US personnel pay US tax and Australian personnel pay Australian tax. This is consistent with the elective provisions of the GOA/US treaty governing tax treatment for both Australians residing in the US and Americans residing in Australia.
(b) As per (4) (a), tax treatment is governed by treaty. We believe most US citizens exercise the provisions to pay US taxes.
(5) (a) Refer to part (4) (a). Information on the Australian and US tax provisions are publicly available.
(b) The differences are not governed by the Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap or contractor policy, but by the election employees make under the provisions of the tax treaty referenced in part (4).
(6) (a) Paid according to US industrial relations system.
(b) Refer to part (6)(a).
(c) Paid according to Australian industrial relations system.

(7) (a) This information can be found in relevant Certified Agreements for Australian citizens. For all contractor employees, this information is considered competition sensitive and generally not releasable. Raytheon employees are covered under the Space Tracking Award 1998, as modified by the Raytheon E-Systems Inc, Certified Agreement 1999.
(b) US personnel are employed under the US industrial relations system and Australian personnel are employed under the Australian industrial relations system.
(8) (a) Paid in US dollars funds, via a bank deposit into US financial institutions.
(b) Refer to part (8)(a).
(c) Paid in Australian dollars, via cheque or bank deposit into Australian financial institutions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the United States of America (US) draft 2004 Defense Authorization Bill, which, according to the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 March 2003, was to be sent to Congress in the week beginning 9 March 2003.
(2) Has the US Administration provided Australia with a copy of the draft bill.
(3) Is it the case that the bill proposes to lift the ban on the development of nuclear weapons with an explosive yield of up to 5 kilo tonnes.
(4) Can the Minister confirm that this is about one-third the size of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.

(5) Does the Government agree that if the bill is passed, and these weapons are developed, the move could set off a global arms race; if so, what advice has the Australian Government provided to the US Administration in relation to these weapons.
(6) Has the Government inquired of the US Administration the purposes to which such weapons would be put.
(7) Does the Government agree with speculation that they will be used to eliminate nuclear, chemical and biological weapons produced by nations such as Iraq, North Korea and Iran.

(8) Is the Government satisfied from the most recent report by the Executive Chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, Dr Blix, that it is unlikely that Iraq has underground bunkers storing chemical, biological or nuclear weapons.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(3) The United States (US) Administration's draft of the bill includes a proposal to rescind the prohibition on research and development of low-yield (less than 5 kiloton) nuclear weapons. The Full Committee mark-ups of the bill are not likely to be ready for several months. The US Administration has previously been authorised by Congress to undertake feasibility studies into the option of modifying existing weapons to improve earth-penetrating capability.
(4) Yes.

(5) The Government will monitor the development and passage of the bill and will develop its policy responses accordingly. The US Administration has stated that it has not changed its policy on the use of nuclear weapons and that the high threshold for their use remains unchanged. The US Administration has also stated that it has no plans to resume critical testing of nuclear weapons or to break the existing voluntary moratorium on such tests.
(6) No. The US Administration has not made any decision to develop or deploy new nuclear weapons and, as far as we are aware, no such decisions are under active consideration.
(7) The Government does not respond to speculative statements.

(8) We expect the question of whether Iraq has underground bunkers storing weapons of mass destruction to be the subject of investigations by Coalition forces after the cessation of the military conflict in Iraq.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Government of the United States of America approached the Australian Government asking for a contribution to, or cooperation with, FutureGen, a proposal to build a coal-fired power station that purportedly emits no carbon dioxide; if so: (a) what was the request; and (b) when was it made.
(2) Does the Government support FutureGen.
(3) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to FutureGen; if so, can details be provided.

(4) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to any other international project relating to the capture, transport and underground storage of carbon dioxide: if so, can details be provided.

(5) Will the Government attend the meeting to be held by the Bush Administration at the end of June 2003 to discuss FutureGen and other efforts to store carbon dioxide underground; if so: (a) what is the purpose and the agenda for the meeting; and (b) who will attend the meeting.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Minister representing the Prime Minister, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The United States Government has not approached the Australian Government to provide funding or in-kind support for FutureGen. However, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham has announced that the United States may use the opening meeting of the US Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum in June 2003, to invite other nations to join the FutureGen initiative.

(2) The Australian Government supports the development of initiatives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including zero emission technologies. Australia relies on coal for 85% of its domestic electricity and coal will remain the primary fuel for power generation in the foreseeable future.
The Australian Government considers that FutureGen will make a valuable contribution in developing and demonstrating leading edge technologies that have direct application to Australia.
(3) The Australian Government, whilst supporting initiatives for the development of zero emissions technologies, has provided no funding or in-kind support to the FutureGen project.

(4) The Australian Government's support for international projects on the capture, transport and storage of carbon dioxide, has been directed at facilitating international collaboration including through the International Energy Agency, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, and bilateral agreements, involving the Australia-United States Climate Action Partnership and Australia's Practical Collaboration on Climate Change with Japan.

Support has also included financial assistance given to the GEODISC program undertaken by the Cooperative Research Centre for Greenhouse Gas Technologies (CO2CRC) and facilitation of the CO2CRC's programs both domestically and internationally. Other assistance has included Australian Greenhouse Office support for an Australian lead author on the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report and sponsorship of the CO2CRC's attendance at the IPCC Regina meeting in Canada.

(5) The Australian Government believes the Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum, being initiated by the United States, is an important vehicle to enhance the international collaboration needed to address the technical, legal and policy issues associated with carbon sequestration. Australia will, therefore, be an active participant in the Leadership Forum and is currently considering the composition of its delegation to the Forum.

The United States anticipates that the Forum will provide an opportunity for Ministerial-level representatives to discuss the growing body of research and technologies for carbon capture and sequestration. The Forum could provide an opportunity to plan future, multilateral carbon sequestration projects. A draft agenda for the Forum has not yet been circulated.
Other invitees include; Brazil, Canada, China, Colombia, the European Commission, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Norway, the Russian Federation, South Africa and the United Kingdom.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 13 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Government of the United States of America approached the Australian Government asking for a contribution to, or cooperation with, FutureGen, a proposal to build a coal-fired power station that purportedly emits no carbon dioxide; if so: (a) what was the request; and (b) when was it made.
(2) Does the Government support FutureGen.
(3) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to FutureGen; if so, can details be provided.

(4) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to any other international project relating to the capture, transport and underground storage of carbon dioxide: if so, can details be provided.

(5) Will the Government attend the meeting to be held by the Bush Administration at the end of June 2003 to discuss FutureGen and other efforts to store carbon dioxide underground; if so: (a) what is the purpose and the agenda for the meeting; and (b) who will attend the meeting.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The United States Government has not approached the Australian Government to provide funding or in-kind support for FutureGen. However, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham has announced that the United States may use the opening meeting of the US Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum in June 2003, to invite other nations to join the FutureGen initiative.

(2) The Australian Government supports the development of initiatives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including zero emission technologies. Australia relies on coal for 85% of its domestic electricity and coal will remain the primary fuel for power generation in the foreseeable future.
The Australian Government considers that FutureGen will make a valuable contribution in developing and demonstrating leading edge technologies that have direct application to Australia.
(3) The Australian Government, whilst supporting initiatives for the development of zero emissions technologies, has provided no funding or in-kind support to the FutureGen project.

(4) The Australian Government's support for international projects on the capture, transport and storage of carbon dioxide, has been directed at facilitating international collaboration including through the International Energy Agency, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, and bilateral agreements, involving the Australia-United States Climate Action Partnership and Australia's Practical Collaboration on Climate Change with Japan.

Support has also included financial assistance given to the GEODISC program undertaken by the Cooperative Research Centre for Greenhouse Gas Technologies (CO2CRC) and facilitation of the CO2CRC's programs both domestically and internationally. Other assistance has included Australian Greenhouse Office support for an Australian lead author on the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report and sponsorship of the CO2CRC's attendance at the IPCC Regina meeting in Canada.

(5) The Australian Government believes the Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum, being initiated by the United States, is an important vehicle to enhance the international collaboration needed to address the technical, legal and policy issues associated with carbon sequestration. Australia will, therefore, be an active participant in the Leadership Forum and is currently considering the composition of its delegation to the Forum.

The United States anticipates that the Forum will provide an opportunity for Ministerial-level representatives to discuss the growing body of research and technologies for carbon capture and sequestration. The Forum could provide an opportunity to plan future, multilateral carbon sequestration projects. A draft agenda for the Forum has not yet been circulated.
Other invitees include; Brazil, Canada, China, Colombia, the European Commission, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Norway, the Russian Federation, South Africa and the United Kingdom.

question.para: (1) Has the Government of the United States of America approached the Australian Government asking for a contribution to, or cooperation with, FutureGen, a proposal to build a coal-fired power station that purportedly emits no carbon dioxide; if so: (a) what was the request; and (b) when was it made.
(2) Does the Government support FutureGen.
(3) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to FutureGen; if so, can details be provided.

(4) Has the Government committed funding, or other support, to any other international project relating to the capture, transport and underground storage of carbon dioxide: if so, can details be provided.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 March 2003:

question.para: (1) With reference to section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992, which allows the Government to impose conditions on tobacco advertising at the Australian Formula One Grand Prix: What conditions were set for the March 2003 race; if no conditions were set, why not.
(2) Given the Government's announcement some time ago that this exemption from the Act would be phased out by October 2006: (a) what form will the 'phasing out' take; and (b) when will it commence.

(3) Given that an exemption from the Act relies on a case being made for economic hardship: Was the case for economic hardship made in respect of the March 2003 race; if so, can details be provided; if not, why was an exemption granted.
(4) Given that the European Commission has determined that there will be no tobacco advertising or sponsorship of formula one races from 2005: Will Australia follow suit; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The conditions set for the 2003 Australian Grand Prix were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Special Gazette No. S 270 dated Thursday, 18 July 2002.

(2) The phasing out of the section 18 exemption was secured by the 2000 amendment to the Act and has therefore already commenced. No new events have been able to apply for an exemption since 1 October 2000. Since that date, one event (the Ladies Masters Golf) which was eligible to apply for an exemption under section 18 of the Act, has already secured alternative sponsorship, and consequently does not have tobacco advertising.

(3) Section 18 of the Act requires the Minister to be satisfied that the event is of international significance and that failure to specify the event would be likely to result in the event not being held in Australia. The Government is satisfied that these requirements were met in the application from the Australian Grand Prix Corporation.

(4) No, because the legislated date of 1 October 2006 allows an appropriate period for event organisers to negotiate alternative sponsorship arrangements, and ensures that States are not financially disadvantaged by the loss of these events.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 19 March 2003:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 971 (Senate Hansard, 5 February 2003, p. 8663):
(1) Will the Minister table, or can copies be provided, of all the relevant environment plans.
(2) What are the minimum requirements to satisfy the Minister that an environment plan ensures environmental protection including no impact on cetaceans.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. The general publication of Environment Plans is prohibited under section 150B of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.
(2) Environment Plans are assessed by State and NT Designated Authorities pursuant to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and supporting State legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

question.para: (1) How many tonnes of beef did Australia export to the Russian Federation in each of the following years: (a) 2000; (b) 2001; and (c) 2002.
(2) How many tonnes of pork did Australia export to the Russian Federation in each of the following years: (a) 2000; (b) 2001; and (c) 2002.
(3) How many tonnes of poultry did Australia export to the Russian Federation in each of the following years: (a) 2000; (b) 2001; and (c) 2002.
(4) Has the Russian Federation decided to impose tariff rate quotas on imported beef, pork and poultry; if so: (a) how will the quotas be set; and (b) when will they be implemented.
(5) How will the quotas impact on Australian exports of beef, pork and poultry.
(6) How many processors will be affected.
(7) When was the Australian Government first informed of the decision to impose quotas on beef, pork and chicken.
(8) What representations did the Australian Government make to the Russian Federation in relation to this matter.
(9) What tariff or other trade barriers restrict the export of Australian wool, sugar, meat and dairy products to the Russian Federation.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The following data is based on information from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
(a) 2,229 tonnes, of which 2173 tonnes is frozen beef
(b) 6,837 tonnes, of which 6623 tonnes is frozen beef
(c) 5,187 tonnes, of which 5044 tonnes is frozen beef
(2) (a) 0.6 tonnes
(b) 80 tonnes
(c) 528 tonnes
(3) (a) nil
(b) nil
(c) 253 tonnes
(4) Yes.

(a) (i) For frozen beef (tariff heading 0202), the tariff rate quota (TRQ) volume will be 420,000 tonnes per annum, and 315,000 tonnes for the final nine months of 2003. The in-quota tariff rate will be 15 per cent or 0.20 Euro/kg if higher. The out-of-quota tariff rate will be 60 per cent or 0.60 Euro/kg if higher.
(ii) Russian imports of fresh or chilled beef (tariff heading 0201) are not subject to the TRQ.

(iii) For fresh, chilled or frozen pork (tariff heading 0203), the in-quota volume will be 450,000 tonnes per annum, and 337,000 tonnes for the final nine months of 2003. The in-quota tariff rate will be 15 per cent or 0.25 Euro/kg if higher. The out-of-quota tariff rate will be 80 per cent or 1.06 Euro/kg if higher.

(iv) Ninety per cent of the tariff rate quota volume for beef and pork will be allocated on the basis of historical imports by Russian importers over the three year period from 2000 to 2002. The remaining 10 per cent will be allocated by Dutch auction.

(v) An import quota will apply to poultry meat imports, which will be set at 1.05 million tonnes per annum, and 744,000 tonnes for the final eight months of 2003. A special industrial-use quota will also be set at 268 tonnes per annum, and 190 tonnes for the final eight months of 2003.

(vi) The import quota on poultry meat will be allocated on the basis of historical imports by Russian importers over the three year period from 1999 to 2001, and traditional suppliers of poultry will be allocated country-specific quotas.
(b) (i) Tariff rate quotas on beef and pork - 1 April 2003.
(ii) Import quota on poultry - 1 May 2003.

(5) The measures will restrict global access to the Russian market for these products. Although Australia may be able to maintain its current export levels given that ninety per cent of the Russian tariff rate quota will be allocated on the basis of historical imports, Australian exporters will still need to compete with other countries for a share of the tariff rate quota. Much will depend on how Russia administers the distribution and utilisation of the tariff rate quota.
(6) Based on data collected over the past 13 months, 55 processors of frozen beef and five processors of pork engaged in export to Russia and could potentially be affected.

(7) The Australian Government received unofficial reports of Russia's decision to implement tariff rate quotas on 29 January 2003. These reports were confirmed by the Russian authorities on 31 January 2003.

(8) Our Ambassador in Moscow and our WTO mission in Geneva have both made several rounds of high-level representations to the Russian authorities to state our opposition to the introduction of these TRQs. They have also pressed the Russian authorities to minimise any disruption to existing trade, and are seeking early phase-out commitments. I have written to Mr Gref, Russian Minister for Economic Development and Trade, emphasising my considerable concern at the introduction of these TRQs.

(9) Tariffs for wool, meat and dairy products range between 10 and 20 per cent. A tariff rate quota applies to raw sugar imports and under current Russian law no developed country supplier (including Australia) has access to this tariff rate quota. Russia's quarantine and certification regime imposes restrictions on Australian exports of wool (especially greasy wool), meat and dairy products.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Did the United States of America (US) file a case against Canada in the World Trade Organization, on 17 December 2002, requesting consultations on the wheat trading practices of the Canadian Wheat Board.
(2) Did Canada agree to consult with the US; if so, on what date.
(3) Did Australia seek to join the consultations; if so, on what date.
(4) Why did Australia seek to join the consultations.
(5) Did other countries seek to join the consultations.
(6) Did the consultations proceed; if so, on what date or dates.
(7) Did the US seek the formation of a World Trade Organization dispute settlement panel on 6 March 2003 concerning the wheat trading practices of the Canadian Wheat Board.
(8) Has Australia sought to join the dispute as a third party.
(9) What advice has the Minister sought from his department, the Attorney-Generals Department or external sources in relation to this action.
(10) What direct or indirect implications does the US action against Canada have for the export monopoly vested in AWB (International) Limited.

(11) What advice has the Minister sought from his department, the Attorney-Generals Department or external sources in relation to the threat, if any, to the export monopoly powers of AWB (International) Limited.
(12) Did the Bush Administration develop a four-part plan in February 2002 in relation to US grain exports, including a policy objective of eliminating all export monopolies in agriculture.
(13) What implications does this policy objective have for Australia's existing export monopoly arrangements.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes, I am not aware of the date Canada agreed to consult with the US.
(3) Yes, 24 December 2002.

(4) Participation as a third party enables WTO members not directly involved in the dispute to observe certain parts of the proceedings and provide their perspective on the issues that are subject to dispute if they desire.
(5) Yes, the EC, Japan and Mexico also made requests to be third parties in the consultations.
(6) Yes, on 31 January 2003.
(7) Yes.
(8) Not to date.
(9) I instructed officials in my department to request third party status in the US/Cananda WTO dispute consultations on wheat on 24 December. I have received updates on developments since then.

(10) The case has no direct implications for the export monopoly vested in AWB (International) Limited. It is too early to speculate on any possible indirect implications on Australia's single desk exporters.
(11) None.

(12) The U.S. four-part plan launched in February 2002 in relation to grain exports included a “commitment to vigorously pursue comprehensive and meaningful reform of monopoly state trading enterprises in the WTO agriculture negotiations.”
(13) The direct implications would depend on the outcome of the WTO agricultural negotiations in the Doha round.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 20 March 2003:

question.para: With reference to the announcement on World No Tobacco Day, 31 May 2002, by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing that there was to be a review of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 to ensure its provisions are keeping pace with emerging advertising and marketing practices that entice people to smoke:
(1) Was the review commenced within two months as announced; if not, when did it commence.
(2) Can details be provided of the appointees to the expert advisory panel.
(3) (a) What stages have been identified for the review; and
(b) Which of those have been completed to date.
(4) What public consultation has been conducted.
(5) Has the review examined the effectiveness of the new graphic warnings on tobacco packaging introduced in Canada in 2003.
(6) What is the expected date of completion of the review.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The review did commence within two months as announced.
(2) Details of the appointees to the expert advisory panel are available on the Department's website.

(3) (a) An issues paper will be released for public consultation shortly. The period of consultation will be followed by an analysis of submissions received and recommendations made by the expert advisory panel regarding possible amendments to the legislation.
(b) None of these stages have been completed to date.
(4) No public consultation has been conducted to date.

(5) The review has not examined the effectiveness of the new graphic warnings on tobacco packaging introduced in Canada in 2003. Health warnings on tobacco packaging in Australia are the subject of a current separate review.
(6) I expect a report on the outcome of public consultation by the end of June 2003. The completion date for the review will depend on whether legislative amendments are required to the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 20 March 2003:

question.para: With reference to the conference on the hydrogen economy to be held in Broome in May 2003:
(1) Why is it being held in such an expensive and inaccessible location.
(2) Why is tidal power singled out for special focus.
(3) Who is paying for the conference.
(4) What provision has been made to enable community participants to attend the conference, through scholarships, heavily discounted registration fees and assistance with travel costs.
(5) When will the proceedings be published and made available.
(6) (a) Who are the members of the High Level Advisory Group;
(b) Who are they advising; and
(c) What are they advising on.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Broome has been chosen as the location for the conference as a means of showcasing the potential to produce hydrogen from the significant tidal energy resources of the Kimberley region and from Western Australia's natural gas reserves. The location also enables potential regional development opportunities associated with energy from hydrogen to be highlighted.

(2) The tidal energy resources of the Kimberley region have the potential to produce renewable energy on a large scale. Development of this resource could provide energy to produce hydrogen and realise a clean, renewable, flexible and cost effective fuel to meet Australia's future energy needs.
(3) The cost of the conference is being met by delegates' registration fees and funding provided through the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources.

(4) Conference registration fees, inclusive of GST, have been set at $880 for registrations received prior to 31 March 2003; $990 for registrations received prior to 2 May 2003; and $1100 for registrations received after 2 May. The cost of conference registration is being part-funded by the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources in order to encourage participation by interested parties. Single-day registration is available to encourage, in particular, participation from Broome and the Kimberley region.
(5) Proceedings for the conference will be produced in June-July 2003 and will be accessible through the website of the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources.

(6) (a) The High Level Advisory Group comprises Mr Greg Bourne, Regional President, BP; Ms Lindley Edwards, CEO of VentureBank; Dr Joel Swisher, Principal Team Leader, Energy and Resource Practice, Rocky Mountain Institute, Colorado, USA; and Mr Simon Whitehouse, Director, Alternative Transport Energy, Department of Planning and Infrastructure, Western Australia.

(b) The High Level Advisory Group advises the consulting team, ACIL Tasman-Parsons Brinckerhoff, that is undertaking the national hydrogen study on behalf of the Government. An interim report from the study will be presented to the Broome conference.
(c) The High Level Advisory Group provides expert advice on strategic international and domestic issues relevant to the national hydrogen study.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

question.para: Has the Minister made a declaration exempting the Commonwealth and all relevant Commonwealth agencies from the operation of section 28 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 in relation to the Government's actions in the war on Iraq; if so, can a copy of that written declaration be tabled.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Minister for the Environment and Heritage under subsection 28(3) of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, in the interest of Australia's defence and security declared “that actions, as deemed appropriate by the Commonwealth Government, undertaken outside the Australian jurisdiction in relation to the training, deployment and operation of members of the Australian Defence Force in the Persian Gulf region in support of any military action against Iraq, are actions to which section 28 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not apply.”

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 27 March 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the infection rate for hepatitis C in Australia.
(2) (a) How much funding goes to prevention services; and (b) how long will this funding continue and at what rate.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The infection rate for hepatitis C in Australia in the year 2001 was 87.3 (age standardised rate per 100,000 population). The number of diagnoses of hepatitis C infection in 2001 was 16,734.
(Source: HIV/AIDS, viral hepatitis and sexually transmissable infections in Australia: Annual Surveillance Reports 1997-2003).

The number and rate of diagnoses of hepatitis C infection in the year 2003 will not be available until the 2003 HIV/AIDS, viral hepatitis and sexually transmissable infections in Australia: Annual Surveillance Report is published during 2003. This is due to the need to adjust data for reporting delays and to collate data gathered from many sources.
(2) (a) Commonwealth funding to prevention initiatives has been provided through the

1999-2000 Hepatitis C Education and Prevention Budget Initiative. This Initiative totalled $12.4 million over four years to support hepatitis C education and prevention initiatives at both the national and State and Territory level. Approximately $6.6 million of the Initiative was funding to States and Territories to develop and implement hepatitis C education and prevention programs. The remainder was allocated to national hepatitis C education and prevention initiatives.
National hepatitis C education and prevention activities conducted under the Initiative included:
· education programs for GPs, and complementary resources and training for nurses, ambulance workers and dentistry workers;
· a national project on HIV/AIDS and hepatitis C awareness for people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds; and

· enhancement of the capacity of established national community-based organisations to provide targeted education for those at risk of infection, and health maintenance and support for those already affected.

Additional funding was allocated within the Department for the 2002-03 financial year to support a range of national education and prevention projects contracted to peak national community-based organisations.

(b) The 1999-2000 Hepatitis C Education and Prevention Budget Initiative lapses on 30 June 2003. Decisions on future funding for hepatitis C education and prevention, including the rate of funding, will be made in the context of the forthcoming Federal Budget.
